Will the Council make a statement on the recent decision by the French and German governments to provide assistance to pig producers in France and Germany and give an assessment of the extent to which this will create an unfair advantage over producers in other Member States?

Answer

On 28 and 29 September 1998 the Council noted the serious crisis in the pigmeat sector caused by an increase in production in 1998 and the collapse of markets, particularly in Russia.

Nevertheless, it is not for the Council to take up a position on the granting of national assistance, since such matters fall within the Commission's sphere of competence as guardian of the Treaty in the field of competition.

Question No 7 by Giorgos Dimitrakopoulos (H−0949/98)

Subject: Selection of Presidency of trade mark Office

In view of attempts to circumvent the provisions of Regulation 40/94(2) which provides for an open selection procedure, following preliminary procedures, in respect of the method for the automatic renewal of the term of office of the President and Vice‐Presidents of the trade mark Office in Alicante, what steps does the Council intend to take to ensure the transparency and legality of the selection of the Presidency of this Office and compliance with this Regulation?

Answer

The proposal for renewing the terms of office of the President and Vice‐Presidents of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (trade marks, designs and models) has been referred to the Council. I can assure the honourable Member that the Council will give a ruling on this proposal in accordance with the Treaty and the relevant provisions on the Community trade mark.

Question No 8 by Sören Wibe (H−0950/98)

Subject: Turmoil in the world's financial system

Has the Council discussed any joint financial and monetary policy measures to alleviate the effects of the current global financial crisis?

Answer

European Union Ministers of Finance and Economy have launched a discussion on the means to strengthen their contribution to the stabilisation of the international financial situation, and they have also asked the Monetary Committee to pursue work on international financial issues with a view to facilitating the process of coming to a common view on such issues within the Council.

In the context of the informal meeting in Vienna, the President of the ECOFIN Council on 26 September stated to the press, inter alia , that ‘The role of the IMF in crisis prevention is increasingly important. We agreed on the urgency of the early implementation of the IMF quota increase and establishment of the New Arrangements to Borrow'.

Question No 9 by Gerard Collins (H−1028/98)

Subject: Low interest rates

In view of the risk of worldwide recession leading to a slow‐down in economic growth in the European Union, can the President‐in‐Office indicate if the Council will actively pursue a policy of encouraging low interest rates in European Union countries in order to ensure that business and industry will have access to investment funds for job‐creation and expansion purposes?

Answer

The Council considered in the broad economic policy guidelines for 1998/1999 that the high level of price stability attained by participating Member States (inflation rate of below 2 %) will allow for monetary conditions favourable to economic growth. Maintenance of a high degree of price stability will allow in turn for convergence of official interest rates in participating Member States to a common low euro‐area rate by the end of 1998. Sound budgetary positions will help to keep long‐term interest rates at a low level, thereby generating a crowding‐in of private investment.

Question No 10 by Freddy Blak (H−0952/98)

Subject: End of duty‐free sales in the EU

Duty‐free sales in the EU will come to an end on 30 June 1999. The 24th recital of Council Directive 92/12/EEC(3) states that before their abolition ‘a certain period of time will be required to take the necessary measures to alleviate both the social repercussions in the sectors concerned and regional difficulties... which might arise'.

In a reply to the Ombudsman the Commission takes the view that it is not required to carry out an analysis of these problems, stating that it had never been the Council's intention to impose such an obligation on the Commission. This was confirmed when the Economy and Finance Ministers meeting in the Council discussed the question in November 1996. As these were informal discussions, the conclusions were not recorded in the official minutes, but the matter was again discussed by the Council of Economy and Finance Ministers on 19 May 1998 with the same result.

Will the Council confirm the Commission's reading of the Council's conclusions and explain how this view is in keeping with the above directive?

Question No 11 by Mark Killilea (H−1005/98)

Subject: Abolition of Duty Free

Would the President‐in‐Office not agree that it is now perhaps time to revisit the issue of duty free abolition, not only in the light of the social and economic difficulties that will arise next year and the resultant negative impact on some Member States' already fragile economies, but also to take account of the sentiment voiced during the recent meeting of Heads of State that decisions taken by the EU should be understood by ordinary EU citizens as being necessary for the future development of the EU and not merely to satisfy a dogmatic principle that is no longer relevant in today's economic reality?

Question No 12 by John Cushnahan (H−1019/98)

Subject: Duty‐free sales

At the recent Heads of State summit, Chancellor Klima stated that all EU policy should be judged on whether it was proportionate and added value to the EU decision‐making process. At the same meeting, it was decided that tackling unemployment should top the EU agenda.

How can these statements be reconciled with the proposed abolition of intra‐EU duty‐free and tax‐free sales on June 30 1999, when the indications are that the result will be substantial job losses?

Question No 13 by Mark Watts (H−1026/98)

Subject: Duty‐free sales

Which customs authority will be responsible for monitoring the payment of excise duties in respect of sales on board ferries or aircraft following the abolition of intra‐EU duty‐sales from 1 July 1999?

Joint answer

According to the Council's basic decision from 1992, tax‐free sales for intra‐Community travellers do not fit in with the concept of an internal market without fiscal frontiers. Nevertheless, the Council decided in 1992 to maintain the situation of duty‐free shops on a temporary basis until the end of June 1999. This decision was primarily motivated by the concern that Member States may need more time to alleviate both the social repercussions in the sector concerned and regional difficulties particularly in border regions which might arise from the abolition of tax‐free sales.

At the outcome of the discussion at the ECOFIN Council of 19 May 1998 the Council stated that the Commission will clarify in a Working document the instruments available to Member States for addressing the consequences of the abolition of duty‐free sales to intra‐Community travellers on 30 June 1999.

Finally, in answer to Mr Watts"s question, will he please refer to Article 8 of Directive 92/12/EEC.

Question No 14 by Anne McIntosh (H−0954/98)

Subject: Duties levied report

When will the Council of Ministers next receive the Commission's report on duties levied throughout the European Union?

Answer

At the moment, the Council does not have any information on the Commission's intentions as regards the submission of a report on duties levied.

I would nevertheless draw the honourable Member's attention to the fact that, given that the Commission is the author of the report in question – as the honourable Member makes clear in her question – that institution will no doubt be better placed to provide the information requested.

Question No 15 by Olivier Dupuis (H−0957/98)

Subject: Indictment of President Milosevic

At the worst stage of the war in Bosnia the Union, or rather the Member States, failed, for somewhat formalistic and certainly questionable and questioned reasons – the fact that the command structure was headed by various countries, causing a lack of continuity – and, no doubt, for far less worthy reasons, to give political support to the indictment of Mr Milosevic while doing so in the case of Mr Mladic and Mr Karadzic. Today the authorities in Belgrade, and therefore Mr Milosevic, are directly responsible for the policy being pursued in Kosovo. There is, moreover, no denying that under this policy war crimes and crimes against humanity have been committed in Kosovo. Does the Council not feel, therefore, as Parliament stated on 8 October 1998, that all the conditions are now satisfied for it to join with the Member States in supporting the indictment of Mr Milosevic before the Court responsible for ruling on the crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia, which, as we know, is competent in this matter?

Answer

The Council fully shares the honourable Member's assessment that the primary responsibility in the origin of the crisis in Kosovo rests in Belgrade.

Furthermore, the Council notes that the Prosecutor of ICTY has expressed the view that the situation in Kosovo represents an armed conflict within the terms of the Tribunal's mandate.

The Council condemned in the strongest terms those responsible for recent atrocities in Kosovo and called upon the authorities in Belgrade immediately to investigate, identify and punish those responsible. It called on all concerned to cooperate fully with ICTY in the investigation of possible violations within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal.

In this context, the Council decided on 5 October 1998 that an EU expert team consisting of Finnish and other experts will travel to the area once sites to be examined are defined, security of the team guaranteed and all technical aspects arranged.

The Council would however like to caution that atrocities committed in Kosovo have been exploited for propaganda objectives by both parties and that, although most of the atrocities are blamed on the Serb side (special police, para‐military groupings, etc.) it is too early to draw any firm and objective conclusions yet. Nevertheless, the findings of the EU experts team are likely to have political and legal implications that may very well lead to indictments by ICTY.

Question No 16 by Inger Schörling (H−0958/98)

Subject: Antibiotics as pesticides

In a number of European countries, fruit and vegetables are sprayed with pesticides containing antibiotics such as streptomycin, oxytetracycline and casugamin. The first two of these antibiotics are also used as medicines for humans. This is happening at the same time as research shows that increased use of antibiotics entails a greater risk of creating antibiotic‐resistant bacteria.

Does the Council know in what quantities, in what manner and in which countries antibiotics are used as pesticides? Does the Council intend to take any measures in the form of a ban or restrictions? If not, does this mean that a link between the use of antibiotics and the creation of antibiotic‐resistant bacteria is so unlikely that the cautionary principle does not apply? Does the Council, in that case, believe that antibiotics are a suitable pesticide for use in fruit and vegetable growing?

Answer

Council Directive 91/414/EEC concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market, established Community‐wide criteria for the authorisation of active substances used in plant protection products and provides for their evaluation with a view to their inclusion in a Community list.

While waiting for the completion of this list, which is a long‐term exercise because about 800 substances are involved, Member States may authorise products in accordance with the criteria and procedures of the Directive.

The Directive provides that the Commission shall arrange a programme of work for the gradual examination of active substances contained in products authorised by Member States.

The Council does not collect or maintain any technical data on the use of these substances. However, the Council has no reason to doubt that substances authorised by Member States comply with the provisions of the Directive.

Question No 17 by Marialiese Flemming (H−0992/98)

Subject: Irradiation of foodstuffs and consumer information

Is the Council aware of the fact that the majority of people living in the European Union are opposed to the irradiation of foodstuffs?

What measures is the Council planning, in addition to any measures, to provide consumers with unambiguous and comprehensive information on the treatment of foodstuffs and their additives and on the general quality of foodstuffs?

Answer

The Council is aware of the problems raised by the irradiation of foodstuffs. It has therefore adopted a common position on implementing procedures governing the processing, marketing and importing of irradiated foodstuffs and food ingredients. In addition, the Council has agreed to the drawing up of an initial list of products that may be irradiated. The list is to be drawn up in stages in order to progressively establish the internal market, taking into account existing possibilities concerning the analysis of irradiation.

These common positions have been referred to the European Parliament under the codecision procedure provided for in Article 189b of the Treaty.

As the list of products authorised for irradiation is only a beginning, the Council has asked the Commission to submit a proposal before 31 December 2000 that aims to establish a definitive list.

In the meantime, Member States may keep their national bans in place, except for on products that appear on the Community list.

Question No 18 by Nuala Ahern (H−0962/98)

Subject: Council Decision on the Sure Programme

How has the Council contributed to the agreement referred to in Article 3(1) of the Council decision on the SURE Programme to ‘evaluate technical aspects of incidents which have occurred during the transport of radioactive materials, and to learn the lessons for the future? What non‐governmental organisations will be consulted with a view to attaining this objective?

Answer

The Council welcomes the Commission's submission of the proposal for a Council decision adopting a multiannual programme of actions in the nuclear sector for the period 1998‐2002, named the SURE programme, which responds to the wish expressed at the Energy Council of 11 May 1998.

As part of its consideration of this proposal, the Council has accepted the provisions of the third indent of Article 3(1), to which the honourable Member refers in her question, i.e. ‘in the field of the safe transport of radioactive materials: (...) evaluate technically incidents which have occurred during transport and learn the lessons for the future'.

The Council would nevertheless point out that Article 5 of the same proposal stipulates that it is the Commission which is responsible for the financial execution and implementation of the programme, including the provisions cited above.

For the purpose of the programme's implementation, Article 5 also makes provision for the Commission to be assisted by the Committee which is to be established within the overall framework of the multiannual framework programme for actions in the energy sector. The nature of any consultations which the Commission might consider appropriate falls within the sole responsibility of the Commission.

Question No 19 by Niels Sindal (H−0964/98)

Subject: IMF loan to South Korea

In connection with the crisis in South‐East Asia, the IMF gave approximately US$ 57 billion in aid to South Korea. Both the international and South Korean press report that some of that amount has been used for non‐commercial funding of shipbuilding.

In other words, part of the IMF's aid has been used as government subsidies to several South Korean shipyards, which were already operating on unfair market terms. This allocation of funds to the shipyards was clearly in contravention of the terms on which the IMF's aid was provided.

What does the Council intend to do about the already existing situation in which some of the IMF's resources have been passed on to South Korean shipyards?

What will the Council do in future to ensure that IMF resources are used in accordance with the terms on which the funds are provided?

Answer

The Council's bodies have not expressed any views on the question of the use of the IMF loans by South Korea, this appears to be a matter primarily for discussion within the IMF framework itself.

It is understood that the Vice‐President of the Commission, Sir Leon Brittan, in his recent visit to Korea, encouraged the Korean side to pursue the reforms put forward by the IMF. He also drew attention to the need for Korea to dismantle large conglomerates which cause unfair competition in such sectors as shipbuilding or semi‐conductors.

Question No 20 by Caroline Jackson (H−0971/98)

Subject: Persecution of the Baha'is in Iran

What action is the Council taking to bring home to the Iranian government the unacceptable nature of their treatment of members of the Bah'ai community in Iran?

Is there any pressure that the European Union can bring to bear on Iran of an economic nature which might have more effect than any such representations made in the past?

Answer

The Council has on several occasions raised the issue of the situation of the Baha'is in Iran with the Iranian authorities; it has expressed its concern following the 21 July execution of Ruhu'llah Rawhani and the death sentence against other Baha'is. It called upon Iran to take immediate action to ensure that they will not be executed.

The Council does not believe that changes can be brought about by coercive measures which would inflict economic hardship on the Iranian people. It should be recalled that Iran's President Khatami, who was elected in 1997, received almost 70 % of the popular vote on the base of a declared new policy of inter alia political reform and freedom based on the rule of law and human rights. The Council believes that increased contacts and exchanges and an effort to open the economy are the best way to promote human rights in Iran.

Question No 21 by Bernie Malone (H−0983/98)

Subject: Relations between the EU and Iran

Does the Council agree that recent decisions by Iranian courts in which a German businessman's death sentence for unlawful sexual relations with a Muslim woman was upheld and in which followers of the Baha'i religion have been sentence to death, have seriously damaged EU‐Iranian relations? Does the Council agree that decisions like these represent a serious obstacle to a closer relationship?

Answer

The Council is aware of the case of German national Helmut Hofer who has been sentenced to death by an Iranian court of first instance for so‐called illegitimate relations with a muslim woman. The verdict has been appealed and will in due course be heard by the Iranian Supreme Court. Mr. Hofer is receiving full consular attention by the German authorities. At this juncture it would be inappropriate for the Council President to speculate about the outcome and possible repercussions of this case.

Concerning the situation of the Baha'is I shall refer to my answer to oral question No 971 on ‘persecution of the Bahai's in Iran'.

Question No 22 by Alex Smith (H−0974/98)

Subject: Radioactive pollution

Will the Presidency seek an urgent meeting with the eight nations of the Arctic Council to consider the origin of the radioactive pollution measured in Inuit food and arctic plants which, it is alleged in the report to the Inuit Circumpola Council released at their conference in Iqaluit last month, originate from nuclear reprocessing plants at Dounreay in Scotland and Sellafield in England?

Answer

The Council shares the honourable Member's concern with regard to effective protection for the public in the context of nuclear activities.

The Council would point out that the nuclear installations referred to in the question are covered by the commitments of the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community, particularly Chapter III thereof relating to health and safety.

In this context, the Member States are obliged to implement the Community legislation in force, and in particular to ensure that the basic standards for the protection of the health of workers and the general public against the dangers arising from ionising radiation laid down in Directive 96/29/Euratom of 13 May 1996 are strictly complied with.

Moreover, Article 37 of the Treaty provides that the Commission shall deliver an opinion on the possibility that the operation of a nuclear installation might result in the radioactive contamination of the water, soil or airspace of another Member State.

Up to now, the Council has not been contacted by any of the Member States which might be affected in connection with the concerns mentioned by the honourable Member.

Question No 23 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0977/98)

Subject: Council strategy on refugees and immigration

At the beginning of its period in office, the Austrian Presidency presented a detailed strategy document on refugee‐ and immigration‐related issues. The document has been discussed in the Council. The measures proposed have been sharply criticised by refugee organisations as well as by some Member States. What account has the Presidency taken of those criticisms, and in what areas will changes be made to the proposed strategy? How is it planned to implement the measures?

Answer

As I was able to confirm for you during Parliament"s October part‐session, in answer to a question from Mr Hager, the strategy document on immigration and asylum is the result of an initiative of the Presidency and not of the Council. This document has not yet been discussed in the Council. In fact, the Presidency collected the first comments from Member State delegations, either in writing or during the K.4 Committee meeting in October. The Presidency then revised the document and officially sent out the revised version to Parliament by letter dated 7 October 1998. The ministers discussed this in their informal meeting in Vienna on 29 and 30 October. This dialogue will continue within the K.4 Committee as the Council will be called upon to discuss it officially at its next meeting in early December 1998.

Question No 24 by Bernd Posselt (H−1012/98)

Subject: EU Office for Asylum Seekers

How does the Austrian Presidency view the proposal by the Bavarian Interior Minister Günther Beckstein, to the effect that a central EU Office should be established for the allocation of asylum seekers and civil war refugees to the various Member States in relation to their size and population?

Answer

Although the Austrian Presidency was not aware of the proposal mentioned by the honourable Member, I can say that asylum seekers are dealt with at EU level in the framework of the Dublin Convention which, while it does not provide for the physical allocation of asylum seekers, lays down rules for determining the Member State responsible for handling a request for asylum. With regard to other refugees, the Council bodies are currently examining two Commission proposals on the temporary protection of displaced persons and on solidarity or burden‐sharing. The European Parliament has been consulted on those proposals and at this early stage of the proceedings, it would be premature to try to draw any firm orientations as to the possible outcome of the discussions.

Question No 25 by Heidi Hautala (H−0978/98)

Subject: Exchange of information between Member States on environmental activists

According to a Dutch newspaper, the Council of Ministers of Justice and Home Affairs decided in May that the EU Member States would begin monitoring and exchanging information on, for example, activists in environmental organisations and citizens taking part in demonstrations, if they were suspected of crossing borders and endangering public order and security.

Is this newspaper story true? On what basis does the Council define persons likely to endanger public order and security?

Answer

As concerns public order and security, the Council has adopted in 1997 a Joint Action with regard to cooperation on law and order and security (OJ L 147, 5.6.1997, p. 1). At its meeting on 28/29 May 1998 the Council took note of the report on progress made in implementing the 1997 Joint Action (see Press release: 8856/98 PRESSE 170). The report showed that progress has been achieved although existing arrangements for cooperation on public order still need to be improved. The main concern relates to the information exchange system, especially with regard to the timeliness of information and intelligence ahead of organised events. The report points to the necessity of forging closer links between Member States on public order policing.

Question No 26 by Jan Andersson (H−0985/98)

Subject: Council's intentions regarding a switch from taxation of labour to taxation of environmentally hazardous activities

Coordination of taxation policy is an issue attracting an increasing amount of attention. One approach to the subject focuses on the possibility of switching the emphasis so that tax on environmentally hazardous activities is increased while tax on labour is reduced. An internal market such as the European Union provides tremendous scope for coordinating such a switch in taxation at European level.

Will the Council, therefore, say what position it has taken on promoting a switch in taxation whereby tax on environmentally hazardous activities is increased while tax on labour is reduced?

Answer

The Council stresses once again the importance for Member States of creating a tax environment that stimulates enterprise and the creation of jobs. It remains however convinced that further work needs to be done on the implementation of this objective. In this context, the European Council in Dublin welcomed the Commission's intention to continue the discussions on its report on the development of tax systems, presented in October 1996, in a tax policy group, paying particular attention to the effects of this policy on employment.

The Council further notes that, the proposal for a Directive on a common system for the taxation of energy products is translating, for the first time, the Commission's tax strategy into a legislative proposal. Article 1 of the proposal calls on the Member States to give preference to the objective of tax neutrality by reducing the statutory charges on labour at the same time as introducing the new common system for the taxation of energy products. This proposal is still under consideration in the framework of the Council.

Question No 27 by Ulla Sandbæk (H−0987/98)

Subject: Cairo + 5

In view of the forthcoming ICPD + 5 International Forum (The Hague, 8‐12 February 1999) which will review and appraise the implementation of the ICPD Programme of Action five years on, could the Council provide information on what delegation to the Forum is anticipated from the EU institutions and who it will be composed of? Will MEPs be part of the delegation?

Answer

The International ‘ICPD + 5' Forum in The Hague, mentioned by the honourable Member, although being an important event in the ICPD + 5 preparatory process, is not an official UN meeting. Whilst Member States, the European Commission, ECE and the Council of Europe, as well as other bodies, organisations and NGOs are invited to attend, there will be no delegation of the EU as such participating.

As far as the ‘ICPD + 5' process is concerned, the honourable Member's attention is drawn to the Special Session of the UN General Assembly, scheduled for 30 June−2 July 1999, where a review of the implementation of the ICPD Programme of Action will take place.

Question No 28 by Niall Andrews (H−0989/98)

Subject: Halting the recruitment of child soldiers

Will the President‐in‐Office of the Council indicate what measures can be put forward in cooperation with third countries and relevant international organisations to stop the recruitment of ‘child soldiers' in conflict situations?

Answer

The Council attaches the highest priority to the promotion of the Rights of the Child. The EU starts from the fundamental principle that children must live a childhood in peace, freedom, prosperity and security, free of abuse, violence and exploitation. The Presidency, in its address to the 53rd session of the UN General Assembly, highlighted the importance of this issue and called for a global coalition to fight plagues such as sexual exploitation of children, the recruitment of ‘child soldiers' and child labour.

The EU has actively supported the work of Mr Otunnu since his appointment by the UN Secretary‐General as Special Representative for Children in Armed Conflicts, as it had supported his predecessor Mrs Machel. The Presidency and Member States are in particular committed to fostering progress on the text of the draft optional protocol on involvement of children in armed conflicts. Once a text is agreed upon, the EU will encourage all states to adopt the optional protocol.

The EU also welcomes the fact that, under article 8 of the statute of the International Criminal Court, the conscription or enlistment of children under the age of 15 into armed forces or their use to participate actively in hostilities, whether international or internal, are considered a war crime falling under the jurisdiction of the Court. The EU fully supports the principles of the ICC statute and looks forward to its early entry into force.

The EU furthermore regularly raises the issue of the Rights of the Child in its political dialogue meetings with third countries. Where relevant, it notably calls upon parties directly or indirectly involved in conflicts to respect existing international standards and to fight against the use of children as combatants.

Subject: EU housing initiatives

The Housing Ministers were due to meet informally on 22‐23 October 1998 to consider ‘The Impact of Housing Construction, Renovation and Modernisation on Employment'.

Will the Council now outline what conclusions were reached at this meeting and indicate whether it had called upon the Commission to draft a report on housing as an area of general interest, underpinning all other fundamental social rights and, a subject which should be taken into consideration at all levels of decision‐making in the Union?

The ministers responsible for housing in the Member States of the European Union did hold an informal meeting on 22 and 23 October 1998 in Graz, at the invitation of the Austrian authorities. The Council has noted that the issues discussed at that meeting do not fall within the sphere of competence of the European Community and that, consequently, the meeting does not concern it.

The Austrian authorities have indicated that the outcome of the work undertaken at the meeting is available on the presidency's internet server: http: //presidency.gv.at .

Question No 30 by Richard Howitt (H−1001/98)

Subject: Visas for non‐EU citizens

On behalf of my constituent, Mr Gordon Young, I would like to ask why his Ukranian wife, who has an indefinite‐stay visa for Britain, when going on a family holiday to another Member State, namely Greece, was required to go through a lengthy process to obtain a short‐stay visa? Does the Council not recognise that indefinite‐stay visa from Member State to Member State? Must Mrs Young continue to encounter difficulties when travelling around Europe on family holidays?

Answer

1. It is not the Council's normal practice to answer questions about specific cases involving named individuals, because the full facts are not known to it with sufficient certainty.

2. Subject to that caveat , it is still indeed the case under Community law, that a third country national who is legally resident in a Member State may be required to obtain a visa before going to another Member State on holiday, even if he or she is a member of the family of a national of the former Member State. Nevertheless, the applicable Community legislation provides, firstly, that ‘Member States shall afford to such persons every facility for obtaining any necessary visas' and, secondly, that ‘ The visas.... shall be free of charge'.

Question No 31 by Pat Gallagher (H−1002/98)

Subject: A new approach to debt relief for the world's poor

Will the President‐in‐Office of the Council indicate whether or not the Council would agree with the findings of a paper drawn up by Trócaire in Ireland on a new approach to debt relief for the world's poor; that an alternative set of criteria to judge debt sustainability is necessary for the Highly Indebted Poor Country Initiative (HIPC) and that, accordingly, the financial resources needed to pay for basic needs such as education and health as well as for investment in productive capacity should be subtracted from a country's revenue before any demands for debt repayments are calculated. Furthermore, given the prevailing world‐wide economic uncertainty, will the Council state to what extent it has considered the special needs and demands of the world's poorest countries, including the question of debt relief?

Answer

Through its own development instruments and in particular the Lomé Convention, the Community is helping to achieve the objective of alleviating the debt burden, particularly that borne by the poorest and most indebted countries. The Community is aware that significant over‐indebtedness can seriously hinder growth in the countries concerned, compromise their development prospects and threaten their economic and social stability.

I would point out that all aid under the European Development Fund, with the exception of risk capital, is now allocated in the form of grants and that the Community has decided to transform all the special loans granted under conventions prior to Lomé IV into grants. Community support for structural adjustment in the ACP countries is also aimed at remedying the structural shortcomings which generate excess indebtedness. I would stress in this connection that the vast majority of counterpart funds created for this purpose are earmarked for expenditure on health and education in the countries concerned.

It is clear, however, that the problem of debt in poor countries must be the subject of concerted action by all the creditors involved, without which the long‐term debt sustainability of developing economies cannot be guaranteed.

The Union is endeavouring to push, in the context of the multilateral initiatives in which it plays an active part, for more systematic account to be taken of the debt problems faced by poor countries.

In that spirit, the Council decided on 6 July 1998 that the Community would participate fully in the HIPC (Highly Indebted Poor Countries) initiative adopted within the framework of the IMF and the World Bank with the aim of ensuring that the development efforts agreed on by the poorest countries are not thwarted by an excessive burden of debt.

The Council's conclusions on this point provide that each decision on the subject must be taken on a case‐by‐case basis with a clear indication being given of the arrangements, terms and conditions for its implementation. It must be compatible with the methodology of the HIPC initiative.

It is also planned that the Commission will in due course submit a report to Parliament and the Council setting out additional financing needs. On the basis of that report, the Council will take a decision on the Community's future participation in the initiative.

Finally, I would draw attention to the ‘Post‐Lomé' negotiating mandate adopted by the Council on 29 June 1998. According to that mandate, it will be possible for resources to be used to assist highly indebted poor countries eligible to benefit from initiatives approved by international financial institutions in repaying their debt linked to earlier operations under the EDF.

This is a significant innovation in our approach to the debt problems facing poor countries.

Question No 32 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−1004/98)

Subject: Attempt to set aside the Treaties to provide funding for Turkey

The Commission's attempt to change the legal basis for providing Turkey with funding is legally, institutionally and politically indefensible. The aim is to circumvent the Member States' rights deriving from the Treaty on European Union and the unequivocal political conditions for releasing funds for Turkey in accordance with the Copenhagen criteria and the Luxembourg decision. Through its ploy of using Article 130w, which concerns development cooperation, and Article 189c, the Commission is appropriating the Council's powers since unanimity is required for any measure, such as funding for Turkey under the Customs Union, which is not covered by the Treaties.

What will be the Council's response to this Commission stratagem? Will it abide by the Copenhagen and Luxembourg decisions on funding for Turkey and, in particular, will it safeguard the rights of the Member States in regard to matters requiring unanimity, as enshrined in the Treaties?

Answer

The Commission submitted to the Council, on 23 October 1998, two proposals on financial cooperation, in the general framework of the European Strategy for Turkey. The first is based on Article 235 of the Treaty and pertains to the strengthening of the Customs Union with Turkey. The second proposal is based on Article 130 W and pertains to the general economic and social development of Turkey.

At present, the Council is studying these proposals. In the framework of different decisional process, the opinion of the European Parliament concerning these proposals is required.

Question No 33 by Gerhard Hager (H−1009/98)

Subject: Pre‐accession package – Enlargement eastwards

The Austrian Presidency described the conclusion of pre‐accession strategies with all eleven candidate countries in the field of asylum, immigration and visa policy as one of its objectives. It also stated that the Schengen standards should also be achieved even sooner at the applicant countries' southern and eastern borders and that ‘pre‐accession packages' should be concluded with the candidate countries.

Politicians from the eastern countries (Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic) do not, however, seem to share these views.

In Hungary and in the Czech Republic, opposition to an early adoption of EU visa policy is growing. The Polish President cannot imagine imposing strict border checks on the border with Ukraine even after accession. He said he could not reconcile this with his moral principles.

Does the Council still reckon to conclude such pre‐accession packages, and what is the timescale for doing so?

Answer

With regard to pre‐accession strategies with the candidate countries in the areas identified by the honourable Member, allow me to elaborate on the activities undertaken by the Austrian Presidency. In the area of asylum, cooperation with the candidate countries was begun during the United Kingdom Presidency in the framework of CIREA and will be pursued in a joint meeting of CIREA experts with asylum experts from the candidate countries on 20 November. These meetings provide for exchanges of views on asylum related matters and on countries of origin and are already proving important in increasing mutual understanding and awareness.

In the field of migration such meetings have taken place already for some considerable time and at the last one, held in September, partnerships were formed between the Member States and the candidate countries, with the assistance of the Commission, with a view to facilitating the harmonisation of statistical data on illegal immigration. The Presidency has organised a conference on migration at the end of November which should provide a further opportunity to strengthen ties with the candidate countries.

Also, at the end of November, a joint meeting of Visa, CIREFI and Re‐admission Experts will take place with the participation of experts from the candidate countries in Brussels. Of course, the question of imposing visa requirements on certain countries with whom the accession candidates have close ties is a sensitive issue and this will certainly come to the fore in the formal accession negotiations which have just been launched.

As far as controls at external borders are concerned the Presidency organised, at the end of October, a week long seminar to which several of the candidate countries, including Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, were invited. One of the subjects dealt with at the seminar was precisely the protection of the external Schengen border mentioned by the honourable Member. This was backed by practical demonstrations at the external land border and also included airport controls and proved extremely useful for our partners. Other seminars tailored to the geographic situation of the different candidate countries will follow.

Finally let me say that following the adoption by the Council on 29 June 1998 of a Joint Action on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, establishing a mechanism for collective evaluation of the enactment, application and effective implementation by the applicant countries of the acquis of the European Union in the field of Justice and Home Affairs, a working party on collective evaluation has been set up with the task inter alia of preparing and keeping up‐to‐date collective evaluations of the situation in the candidate countries on the enactment, application and effective implementation of the acquis of the Union in the field of Justice and Home Affairs.

Question No 34 by James Fitzsimons (H−1014/98)

Subject: MOX air shipments

As no doubt the Council is aware, public concern in Ireland and elsewhere remains very strong in relation to the operations of Sellafield and the recent go‐ahead for the new MOX plant, which can produce 120 tonnes a year of MOX fuel. Will the Council, in recognising the need to put safety first, call on the Commission to examine and justify the need for the new MOX plant and give assurances that all potential flights involving MOX deliveries to or from Sellafield will be banned along routes crossing or adjacent to Ireland and any other EU Member State?

Answer

The Council would emphasise the great importance which it attaches to nuclear safety in all its forms.

In the specific case of the production of mixed‐oxide fuel, generally known as MOX fuel, in the Sellafield installation, the Council would point out that the relevant provisions of the Euratom Treaty provide for consultation of the Commission.

In fact, this MOX fuel installation was the subject of a Commission opinion of 5 March 1997, pursuant to Article 37 of the Euratom Treaty, on the plan to store radioactive waste resulting from its operation. That opinion concludes that the implementation of the plan is not liable to result in significant radioactive contamination in terms of health, water, soil or airspace in another Member State.

Furthermore, the Commission communicated its views to the Member State concerned pursuant to Article 43 of the Euratom Treaty on 18 September 1995, with regard to all aspects of the investment project in connection with the above MOX fuel installation.

The transport by air of nuclear materials, including MOX fuel, is governed by rules laid down within the framework of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), complemented by those of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO). It is for each country to adopt appropriate national provisions to apply these rules. In this context, provision is made for the possibility for a country not to accept certain flights over its territory under specific conditions.

Question No 35 by Hugh McMahon (H−1016/98)

Subject: Transport Council meeting held on 1 October 1998

Can the President‐in‐Office inform Parliament of the outcome of the Transport meeting held on 1 October and, in particular, whether any progress has been made in negotiations between the Community and the US on the issue of air transport?

Answer

On the subject of negotiations between the Community and the United States in the field of air transport, at its meeting on 1 October 1998, the Council was not able to reach unanimous agreement on giving the Commission an enlarged negotiating mandate.

The Council agreed that work should continue at an appropriate level so that the next Council could reach conclusions on this matter.

It should be recalled that on the basis of a mandate agreed on 25 July 1996, the Commission, on behalf of the European Community, held talks with the United States on 30‐31 October 1996 and 3 April 1997 in Washington and Brussels respectively. These talks centred on the objective of establishing a ‘Common Aviation Area' between the parties concerned. The mandate clearly distinguishes two separate stages of negotiations – the first stage concentrates on regulatory measures and is the only mandate to have been given to the Commission. The second stage would deal with questions relating to market access (such as traffic rights).

However, the United States has indicated to the Commission that it would be prepared to talk about regulatory measures only in the context of negotiations covering all aspects relating to a ‘Common Aviation Area' thus also including questions relating to market access.

In view of this reaction by the United States, the Commission submitted to the Council, on 7 November 1997, a Communication requesting an enlarged mandate authorizing the Commission to open negotiations for an agreement with the US on all aspects of the Common Aviation Area.

This draft mandate is being examined by the Council bodies.

Question No 36 by Jan Bertens (H−1024/98)

Subject: The case of Leonard Peltier

For 23 years now, Leonard Peltier has been serving two life sentences in the Kansas Federal Penitentiary. A few years ago, it was acknowledged that the case against Mr Peltier was not watertight. Nonetheless, he is still in prison, and he is receiving very inadequate medical treatment.

What has the Council done about this matter since Parliament adopted a resolution on Mr Peltier's case in 1994? Does the Council share my view that this case deserves proper treatment by the American authorities? Does it agree that Leonard Peltier should be permitted to consult an outside doctor?

Can the Council assure me that this issue will be raised in the appropriate bilateral meetings?

Answer

The Council is aware that Mr Peltier's case has been closely followed by Amnesty International, which has recently issued a very detailed report on the human rights in the United States. The situation of many prisoners in gaol in the United States is clearly of concern and, in particular, that of those who have been sentenced to death. But the Council cannot take up, especially in democratic countries subject to the rule of law, every case in which there are allegations of miscarriage of justice (allegations not unknown in our own Member States), even from so distinguished a body as the European Parliament.

Question No 37 by Veronica Hardstaff (H−1036/98)

Subject: Ill‐treatment of citizens at passport control

Is the Council aware that some EU citizens are being treated by some immigration officials with hostility and contempt as regards their right to travel freely within the Union? I refer particularly to the case of a young female British citizen, travelling home from Italy to Britain by train via France, who was bullied physically and verbally, prevented from phoning her family or the British Consulate, and had her passport confiscated by French border officials. No doubt the fact that her mother was originally from Ghana, although now a British citizen, was the major factor which prompted the officials concerned to behave as they did.

Would the Council take steps to ensure that all officials within the EU dealing with passport/immigration control receive proper training, including racial awareness courses, to ensure that non‐white Community citizens are not subjected to harassment when exercising their legal right to travel freely within the European Union?

Answer

The Council has no knowledge of the incidents referred to in the honourable Member's question and has therefore had no occasion to discuss them. That said, I must emphasise to the honourable Member that the Council attaches great value to the fact that free movement within the European Union should be guaranteed for all citizens of its Member States.

I would also draw the honourable Member's attention to the fact that no discrimination can be tolerated on the grounds of race, religion, political conviction, etc. within the European Union, since that would constitute a serious attack on the individual freedoms underlying the democratic structure which is the common home of the peoples of our European Community.

Nevertheless, I would point out to the honourable Member that identity checks are a matter for the competent national authorities.

Question No 38 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−1038/98)

Subject: Pre‐accession negotiations with Cyprus and participation of Turkish Cypriot side

Commissioner Van den Broek stated in the European Parliament that pre‐accession talks with Cyprus were progressing smoothly and that there were hopes that the Turkish Cypriots would take part in the process. However, participation by the Turkish Cypriots is not dependent on them as they receive no information and do not take part in taking such decisions. It is dependent on Denktash, who acts only on the orders and in the interests of Ankara.

In the event that Ankara – for its own purposes – drags its heels indefinitely or even vetoes Turkish Cypriot participation in the negotiations, will negotiations with the Cypriot Government be suspended, bearing in mind that the Government actually wants the Turkish Cypriots to take part, and is their participation a condition for the continuation and successful conclusion of negotiations with Cyprus?

Answer

The Council regrets that it has not been possible to achieve a political solution to the continuing division of Cyprus in time for the start of the accession negotiations, and that the invitation of the Cyprus government to include representatives of the Turkish Cypriot community in the negotiations has so far not been taken up. The conclusions of the Council of 5 October 1998 are unambiguous in this respect.

The Council believes that Cyprus's accession to the EU should benefit all communities, including the Turkish Cypriot community, and that it should help to bring about civil peace and reconciliation on the island. In that context, the Union's objective remains a bi‐communal, bi‐zonal federation on the basis of a comprehensive political settlement in accordance with UN Security Council Resolutions. A political settlement would allow the provisions of the Accession Treaty to be implemented throughout the island. Progress towards accession and towards a just and viable solution to the Cyprus problem will naturally reinforce each other. The Council reaffirmed its full support for the search for a solution under the aegis of the UN.

Accession negotiations with Cyprus will continue within the framework agreed at the Luxembourg European Council and confirmed by the Cardiff European Council. The Council reiterates the importance it attaches to associating the Turkish Cypriots with the accession process. To this end, the Presidency and the Commission will pursue the necessary contacts.

Question No 39 by Pedro Marset Campos (H−1042/98)

Subject: Peace process in the Middle East

In view of the EU's economic and political importance in the Middle East and noting once again Israel's systematic failure to comply with the Wye Plantation agreements intended to ensure continuity in the peace process (which gives the impression that UN resolutions are being scorned), does the Council not think that it is time for the EU to act as an economic and political power in order to force Netanyahu to comply with the agreements which have been signed? Does the Council intend to meet in order to consider blocking all the agreements concluded between the EU and Israel as a way of forcing the latter to abide by what was agreed at Wye Plantation and in Oslo?

Answer

The Council considers the Wye River Memorandum an important step towards peace and stability in the Middle East. At its 9 November Session the Council condemned the recent acts of terrorism and urged the parties to do their utmost both to forestall extremist actions and to deny success to those seeking to frustrate the Peace Process. The Council President and the Commission, accompanied by the EU Special Envoy, visited the region a few days ago to identify the scope for a significant EU political and economic contribution to the implementation of the Wye River Memorandum.

The situation in the Middle East is complex and the Council does not believe that steps such as those suggested by the honourable Member would contribute to break the deadlock in the Peace Process.

Question No 40 by Liam Hyland (H−1045/98)

Subject: Increasing pensioners' returns on deposit savings

Given the steady and continuing fall in interest rates in the European Union, and bearing in mind the consequent fall in deposit returns for savers, particularly pensioners, has the Council considered this situation and put forward any new ideas aimed at securing fair and better returns, with particular regard to pensioners' savings?

Answer

The Council considered in the broad economic policy guidelines for 1998/1999 that the high level of price stability attained by participating Member States will allow for monetary conditions favourable to economic growth. It is not the task of the Council to take action to influence the returns of specific groups of savers.

Question No 41 by Christine Oddy (H−1049/98)

Subject: Crimes against humanity in Chile during the rule of General Pinochet

Given the evidence of crimes committed against European Union citizens, including torture, disappearances and murder, during the rule of General Pinochet, will the Council of Ministers take the appropriate steps as a matter of urgency to indict General Pinochet on a charge of crimes against humanity?
