The Council is not in a position to answer the honourable Member's question which, in any case, does not come under the competence of the European Union. The answer to this question can only be given by the governments of those Member States, whose citizens were victims of the Pinochet regime.

2. Questions to the Commission

 

Question No 51 by Jürgen Schröder (H−1041/98)

Subject: Impact of the reform of the Structural Funds on the new German Länder

During the 1994‐1999 programming period Saxony, like the other new German Länder, has been an Objective 1 region.

Can the Commission give assurances that this will remain the case during the next programming period from 2000 to 2006, after the return of the Structural Funds?

Answer

The proposal for a general regulation on the Structural Funds, which was approved by the Commission on 18 March, states that the regions eligible for Objective 1 will be those whose per capita GDP, calculated at NUTS level II, in purchasing power standard, is below 75 % of the Community average. The per capita GDP will be calculated using Community data from the last three available years.

Assuming that the general regulation is adopted by the Council, following the assent of the European Parliament, during the second quarter of 1999, the data that will be taken into account will be that for 1994, 1995 and 1996. The data for the regional GDP for 1996 will not be available until the end of this year.

With regard to Saxony, it has a per capita GDP that is 59.6 % of the Community average, on the basis of the data for 1993, 1994 and 1995. This level is therefore well below the threshold of 75 %. Taking into account the data for 1996 should not alter this situation: Saxony should therefore, like the four new German Länder, remain eligible for Objective 1 for the 2000‐2006 period.

Question No 61 by Maj Theorin (H−0967/98)

Subject: Swedish taxes

During the summer, the highest‐ranking person in the Commission with responsibility for taxation said in the Swedish media that Swedish taxes were far too high.

Those taxes are used to finance social insurance, free education for children and young people and a good standard of medical care, which is the same for everyone. A large proportion of the tax revenue is transferred to members of the public in the form of child allowances and housing allowances (which, in accounting terms, is comparable to reducing taxes for the worst‐off in society).

Does the Commission take the view that items of expenditure which taxes are used to pay for should be financed in another way? If so, which ones?

Answer

Indeed, the most recent results from the Commission show that the relation between tax revenues and gross domestic product in Sweden is higher than in any other Member State (in 1997 it was 54.1 % compared to a Community average of 42.6 %).

High taxes are used to finance a large amount of public goods and social redistribution according to the preferences of the citizens of a Member State. The European Commission does not want to pass a judgment on these preferences nor does it want to criticise the amount of taxes or expenditure.

The European Commission endorses however the claim that in many European states taxes on labour are very high and that is detrimental to a reduction of unemployment. The Commission has therefore recommended to reduce the taxation of labour.

How such a reduction could be financed is up to the Member States to decide. Options are a reduction in expenditure or through restructuring their tax systems.

Question No 62 by Jan Andersson (H−0986/98)

Subject: Commission's intentions regarding a switch from taxation of labour to taxation of environmentally hazardous activities

A number of Member States at the present time impose a tax on environmentally hazardous activities. A tax of this kind has the obvious advantage of expanding the potential for achieving an ecologically sustainable society. One possibility afforded by this form of taxation is the ability to switch the burden of taxation so that tax on environmentally hazardous activities increases while tax on labour is reduced, a change which could benefit both the environment and employment. An internal market such as the European Union provides tremendous scope for coordinating such a switch in taxation at European level.

Will the Commission, therefore, say what initiatives it has taken or intends to take to promote a switch in taxation whereby tax on environmentally hazardous activities increases while tax on labour is reduced?

Answer

The taxation of (employed) labour reached a level of 21.6 % of GDP in 1996 while taxes on energy or environmental use stood at 2.2 % of GDP or 0.7 % of GDP respectively (Source: Eurostat, 'Structures of the taxation systems of the EU')

In its White Paper ‘Growth, Competitiveness, Employment (1993) the European Commission recommended to reduce the taxation of labour. How such a reduction is financed is up to the Member States. Options are a reduction in expenditure or an increase of other taxes than labour, eg taxes on energy or environmental use.

The Commission proposals for the taxation of energy products (COM(93)30) which is currently being discussed in the Council, proposes an increase in the existing minimum rates of taxation for existing mineral oil products and expands the Community tax base to all energy products. Article 1 of the proposal urges Member States to offset any additional revenues obtained from energy taxation by reducing statutory charges on labour.

Question No 63 by Pat Gallagher (H−1003/98)

Subject: Amsterdam Treaty objectives and the abolition of duty‐free sales

In the Protocol to the Treaty of Amsterdam on ‘proportionality', it is stated that ‘any action by the Community shall not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaty'.

As the aim to combat unemployment is given priority in the Treaty of Amsterdam, does not the Commission agree that the abolition of duty‐free sales is disproportionate to the stated objective of creating and maintaining employment?

Answer

The decision to abolish duty‐free sales within the Community taken by the Council in 1991 was part of the measures necessary for the implementation of an internal market without fiscal frontiers.

Looking at the overall positive employment effects of the internal market as opposed to possible negative effects of the abolition of duty‐free sales, the Commission does not agree with the honourable Member that the Council's decision must be considered as disproportionate.

Question No 64 by Mark Watts (H−1027/98)

Subject: Duty‐free sales

Under the rules applicable following the abolition of intra‐EU duty‐free sales, six different tax rates will apply to sales of goods on a ferry journey from Portsmouth to Santander. In addition to these six tax rates in respect of goods which are to be taken away, up to three different rates could apply to sales of goods on board for immediate consumption.

Is this the ‘clear, simple and easily enforceable solution' promised by the European Commission?

Answer

The Commission does not agree that six different tax rates will apply to sales of goods on a ferry journey from Portsmouth to Santander. Assuming that the ferry goes direct without any intermediate calls, the goods will be subject, during the whole journey, to UK VAT.

Similar rules will apply in the case of excise duty although in this case the rate to be applied will generally be that of the Member States where the goods have been loaded which could be either Spain or the United Kingdom.

With regard to goods sold for immediate consumption, there will be no change from the current situation since it is only the rules relating to sales of goods to be taken away which will change when duty free sales are abolished.

Provided that the Member States concerned do not change their national rules, such sales can continue to be made tax and duty free.

Question No 65 by Yvonne Sandberg‐Fries (H−1047/98)

Subject: Personal data on the Internet

Although the aim of the EU data protection directive (Directive 95/46/EC)(4) was to ensure that individuals' privacy is better protected, there is some uncertainty about how the rules on the processing of totally harmless personal data on the Internet are to be interpreted in relation to the new law. Many citizens in the Member States, in particular Sweden, have expressed their deep concern that personal names appearing on the Internet could have ended up in a legal grey area.

Will the Commission explain exactly how it is to be possible under the Directive to apply a model which combats abuse without restricting use of the Internet? Does it take the view that the person responsible for a home page in the European Parliament must obtain permission from any person whose name appears on that page? How does it think that compliance with stringent rules on the harmless use of personal data can be ensured in a global network such as the Internet?

Answer

The directive adopted by the Council and the Parliament on the protection of personal data three years ago, addresses all the necessary elements of a modern data protection system in a flexible and technology‐neutral way.

The approach adopted by the Directive is that there are no ‘harmless' or ‘harmful' personal data as such. It depends on the context of a concrete processing operation whether it presents a risk to the individual's privacy or not. The Internet is indeed a high risk area for the privacy of individuals because of its world‐wide accessibility.

The best safeguard is of course that the individual gives his or her consent to a specific use of personal information. But the directive does not make this a requirement in all cases. It also provides for other legitimate grounds for data processing, such as a legitimate interest of the controller of the data, provided it is not overridden by the interests of the individual. The directive foresees as well flexible exemptions from the requirement to inform individuals about the processing of data about them in cases where the data are not directly collected from them, for example if informing them would involve a disproportionate effort.

As regards data processing for journalistic purposes, the directive provides that Member States shall make exemptions as far as necessary to reconcile the right to privacy with the rules governing freedom of expression.

The Directive will help to create the conditions for greater confidence in the Internet and will thus favour its development, not hinder its use, given the various elements of flexibility outlined.

Question No 66 by Christine Oddy (H−1050/98)

Subject: European Company Statute

What progress has the European Commission made on the European Company Statute during the Austrian Presidency?

Answer

The Commission is pleased to provide the following information on the state of progress of the work on the ‘European Company' (SE).

After the progress made by the Luxembourgish and UK Presidencies, the Austrian Presidency has devoted much time and effort to obtaining a political agreement on the regulation and on the directive which defines the role which workers are to play in the SE set‐up.

The Commission hopes that the progress which has been made will enable an agreement to be reached at the Social Affairs Council meeting on 2 December and the extraordinary Internal Market Council meeting which may be convened on 7 December.

Question No 67 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−0922/98)

Subject: Protection of ‘feta' as an exclusively Greek product

The Commission took a decision to recognise the Greek cheese, 'feta', as a product with a protected designation of origin. However, several Member States have appealed to the Court of Justice against this decision. In his proposals relating to the appeal, the Advocate‐General of the Court of Justice argues, with no basis in reality or law, that the right to use the designation ‘feta' should not be granted to Greece alone. The survival of stockfarming in Greece depends almost exclusively on ‘feta' production, as 250 000 stockfarmers, mainly small‐scale operators in mountain us and disadvantaged regions, are involved in goat and sheep farming and the production of genuine ‘feta'. Given, therefore, that the adoption of the Advocate‐General's proposal will cause irreparable damage to this traditional Greek product, will the Commission say how it will intervene in vigorous and effective support of its decision that the designation ‘feta' should be applied solely and exclusively to the product produced in Greece?

Answer

Under Regulation (EC) No 1107/96, the Commission did indeed register the name ‘feta" as a protected designation of origin at Community level.

In the context of the contentious procedure mentioned by the honourable Member, the Commission has already highlighted all the legal, scientific and technical elements that fully justify this registration. Purely for the purpose of illustration, reference was made to the traditional methods of making ‘feta" cheese that date back two thousand years, to the specific character of the geographical area associated with it, to the reputation of the cheese that has been established in a particularly rich bibliography, to the survey carried out among Community consumers by Eurobarometer, and to the conclusions of the Scientific Committee.

Contrary to the suggestions made by the honourable Member, the Commission has absolutely no powers to intervene in the current stage of the procedure pending before the Court of Justice: according to the Court"s rules of procedure, there can be no reaction from a party to the case after the conclusion of an Advocate‐General.

The Commission, trusting in the wisdom of the Community"s supreme court, wholly defers to its decision.

Question No 68 by Ian White (H−0927/98)

Subject: Charges for in‐flight oxygen

Airline passengers suffering from chronic pulmonary disease sometimes require supplementary oxygen equipment in flight. Does the Commission accept that fare discrimination exists between airlines when different charges are made for this?

Answer

Airline passengers suffering from chronic pulmonary diseases may carry their own oxygen equipment on flights, provided that the equipment complies with the relevant rules applicable in the Member States which are in most cases based on JAR‐OPS rules (in this case JAR‐OPS 1.11.60).

However, in cases where a passenger requests the airline to supply such equipment, the company may ask to be reimbursed for costs which are not normally covered by the ticket fare.

The Commission believes that services connected to medical equipment should not be treated differently from other extra services the passenger may ask from the airline. In these cases it is up to the airline's commercial judgment to decide if it should request compensation or not.

Question No 69 by Patricia McKenna (H−0933/98)

Subject: Participation of Commissioners in the Bilderberg Group

Will the Commission fully inform Parliament about the content and conclusions of (or consensus reached by) the Bilderberg meetings attended by various Commissioners over the years, indicating fully which Commissioners attended which meetings since 1954? If not, why not? Will the Commission clarify whether Commissioners attend in their private or official capacities, since on the one hand Bilderberg and the participants normally claim they attend in their private capacities, whereas on the other hand the Commission has formally announced the participation in the past by Mrs Bjerregaard, Mr Monti and Mr Van den Broek; and also Mr Kenneth Clarke and Mr Tony Blair have stated to the House of Commons in the past that they attended in their official capacities, and the full security apparatus of the host state not only protects the participants but also ensures the secrecy of the meetings, including the arresting and charging of journalists reporting on the meetings? Is Mr Monti's membership of the Bilderberg Group Steering Committee fully compatible with the duties and obligations of being a Member of the European Commission pursuant to Articles 155 to 163 of the EC Treaty?

Answer

The Bilderberg meetings are an international forum in which political leaders and economists express their personal views on topics of general interest, particularly in the spheres of foreign policy and world economics. The participants attend meetings in a private capacity and the statements which they make are not binding on the Commission; no resolutions are passed, no votes are taken and no political communiqués are issued.

For the above reasons, the Commission is unable to supply details of the substance and conclusions of such meetings, nor does it have any statistics regarding the participation of its members since the first meeting held in 1954.

Of the current Commission Members, Mrs Bjerregaard and Mr van den Broek attended the 1995 meeting, Mr Monti the 1996 meeting and Sir Leonard Brittan and Mrs Bonino the 1998 meeting. They all spoke in a private capacity at those meetings. Mr Monti was a member of the Steering Committee between 1983 and 1993, before becoming a Member of the Commission in 1995.

Question No 70 by Anneli Hulthén (H−0934/98)

Subject: Ban on cadmium in plastic

One of the Community's aims is to try to make available to people the best products that the market has to offer. An important part of this work is the endeavour to remove or replace harmful substances in goods, particularly where there are satisfactory or better alternatives to the harmful substance.

In its negotiations for membership, Sweden obtained an exemption enabling it to ban the use of the toxic substance, cadmium, in plastic. Perfectly satisfactory and less harmful alternatives to cadmium are used instead. Will the Commission, therefore, say whether it is working to ensure that all citizens of the Union have access to such plastic and that plastic containing toxic cadmium is banned on the Community market? If not, how does the Commission justify allowing the use of harmful substances when there are better alternatives?

Answer

The Commission is committed to implementing Council Resolution 88/C30/01 on a Community action programme to combat environmental pollution by cadmium(5) . In this context it has proposed a whole series of legislative measures including Council Directive 91/338/EEC(6) amending for cadmium Council Directive 76/769/EEC on the approximation of the laws, regulation and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to restrictions on the marketing and use of certain dangerous substances and preparations(7) . Council Directive 91/338/EEC restricts the use of cadmium as a stabilizer in plastics and as a pigment and also for plating.

The Commission is nearing completion of its review with Member States and stakeholders of Directive 91/338/EEC in the framework of the Acts of Accession of Austria, Finland and Sweden. A draft Commission directive, providing for further bans on the use of cadmium as stabilizer and pigment in plastics, has been extensively discussed and will soon be presented for opinion to the committee for adaptation to technical progress of the annexes to Directive 76/769/EEC.

Question No 71 by James Nicholson (H−0939/98)

Subject: Aid to pig producers in France and Germany

Will the Commission make a statement on the recent decision by the French and German governments to provide assistance to pig producers in France and Germany and give an assessment of the extent to which this will create an unfair advantage over producers in other Member States?

Answer

The French Government has notified a package of three measures to the Commission under Article 93 of the EC Treaty. This package consists of the revitalisation of the so‐called Stabiporc mechanism, the postponement of certain social security payments and relief on repayments of loans for previous investments undertaken by pig producers. The Commission has asked the French Government to provide more detailed information in order to assess the compatibility of these measures with the State aid rules laid down by the Treaty.

In Germany, the aid measures for the pig sector were announced before the Federal elections. Following the change of government, implementation of the measures has been suspended, and it is now up to the new government to decide whether to proceed. As a precautionary measure, the Commission has written to the German authorities to remind them of their obligation to notify in advance any new aid measures to the Commission.

The Commission is well aware of concerns that the unilateral payment of State aid to the pig sector may result in a distortion of competition. The commission will investigate all such cases urgently, and if it is found that aid has been paid unlawfully, it will order the repayment of the aid with interest.

Question No 72 by Jaime Valdivielso de Cué (H−0941/98)

Subject: Employment

In 1997, 320 000 jobs went unfilled on account of the EU's lack of people trained in information technology. If the necessary investment in training is not forthcoming, the number of EU job vacancies in this sector will increase to 1.6 million by 2002. These are two of the conclusions which emerged from the recent Conference of Employment and Training in the information society.

What specific measures are being prepared by the Commission in order to fill the vacancies in the above area, given the size of the unemployment problem in Europe?

Answer

This question is particularly timely as the Commission is currently preparing its response to the request from last year's European Council on Employment in Luxembourg to prepare an analysis of the prospects for electronic commerce, open networks and the use of multi‐media for education and training. Indeed, the Commission's analysis – which will be submitted to the European Council in Vienna – indicates that the shortage of qualified IT professionals may be even larger than the 320 000 quoted in the question.

This question highlights a serious structural problem. In the short term, it is magnified by the millennium ‘bug' and the passage to the euro, but the rapid growth in Information Industries and the accompanying demand for labour is the major source of new skill requirements.

As far as qualified personnel are concerned, a major factor is the shortage of third level places in computing in European training and educational systems and this is further accentuated by a strong gender bias in the courses that are available. The Commission does not have direct control over the allocation of resources into education which is the responsibility of Member States. However, in the Commission's submission to the Vienna European Council it will strongly recommend that urgent preventative action needs to be taken including a reallocation of resources into computer courses, an increased emphasis on retraining older workers (and the unemployed) through conversion courses and the development of public‐private partnerships to transparently set curricula content in line with technology development.

The Commission's submission to Vienna will also stress that more than just learning technology, what is important is learning to learn with technology and learning to use information and communicate. The speed and pervasive nature of the changes brought about by the Information Society require a fundamental rethinking of education and training policies. Boosting levels of ICT literacy across the board is essential to succeed in the knowledge‐based economy.

The Commission has already identified the importance of the Information Society in its proposals for the reform of the Structural Funds, and in particular has mainstreamed IS in the European Social Fund which supports the European Employment Strategy.

In addition, the Commission has undertaken a number of specific initiatives addressing the problem of preparing qualified staff for the use of IT and for providing the IT industry and services with the necessary human resources and skills. In particular:

‐ The Action Plan for the competitiveness of the ICT INDUSTRIES: ‘Promoting Skills' is one of the major areas for action and includes a number of initiatives in this field. These go from benchmarking ICT skills in Member States and comparing these with best practice (both in Europe and US), to supporting a specific industry‐led project on ‘ICT skills and job profiles' aimed at establishing and making public a set of skills profiles, based on the current requirements of the industry.

‐ Initiatives have been supported in the context of the Esprit programme. One in particular can be mentioned, the European Computer Driving Licence (ECDL), which provides the assessment and certification of standard knowledge needed for using efficiently IT tools.

Question No 73 by Angela Sierra González (H−0942/98)

Subject: State aid for the Canary Islands

According to the guidelines on state aid for regional purposes (paragraph 4.8), the inclusion of the Canary Islands as a region to which Article 92(3)(c) of the EC Treaty applies would mean that the maximum amount of aid expressed in terms of net subsidy equivalent (NSE) would amount to only 20 % of the total of that aid, as opposed to the 65 % allowed under the same paragraph for section (a) regions.

What would be the effect on the current Canary Islands State Aid Scheme (applied by means of the Economic and Fiscal Arrangements), and in particular on the Canary Islands Special Zone and on other transport and production incentives, if the islands were excluded from the scope of Article 92(3)(a) of the EC Treaty on account of their GDP/PPS exceeding 75 % of the Community average?

Answer

1. With regard to the State aid scheme approved by the Commission on 16 December 1997, it is useful to recall that it concerns certain aid under the Canary Islands Economic and Fiscal Arrangements, such as:

‐ a reduction in the tax base on profits for amounts destined for the investment reserve, up to a limit of 90 % of the retained profits;

‐ tax relief on corporation tax and personal income tax, for the part of those taxes affecting income from the production of material goods;

‐ tax exemptions on stamp duties and registration duties for company documents associated with its establishment, increasing its capital and purchasing assets.

However, the aforementioned State aid scheme does not affect the Canary Islands Special Zone, for which State aid was not notified by the Spanish authorities.

2. As this is an authorised aid scheme, altering the conditions for authorisation before the scheduled time would not depend on the future eligibility of the Canary Islands for the derogation to Article 92(3)(a) of the EC Treaty for the period from 2000 to 2006, but on a possible proposal for useful measures in the framework of the procedure established in Article 92(1) of the EC Treaty.

However, the evaluation of any new State aid for the 2000‐2006 period should, if the case arises, take account of the eligibility of the Canary Islands for one of the regional provisions: that of Article 92(3)(a) or Article 92(3)(c) of the EC Treaty.

Question No 74 by John Iversen (H−0943/98)

Subject: Multi‐resistant bacteria

More and more zoonotic bacteria are becoming multi‐resistant through the use of antibiotic growth‐promoters and the excessive use of antibiotics in veterinary and human medicine.

Does the Commission have an overview of the spread of resistant bacteria in the Member States and what does the Commission intend to do to stop them spreading?

Many Member States have not implemented the zoonosis directive but the Commission has not taken any steps to remedy the situation. Responding to Parliament's report on BSE, the Commission accepted that there had been shortcomings in its monitoring of the implementation of certain Community standards with an important bearing on public health and that there was a need to improve food safety.

Why is the Commission now repeating its faulty monitoring and follow‐up in an area which is even more important to public health than BSE? What steps will the Commission take to put a stop to this inefficiency in the future?

Answer

The Commission is aware of the fact that resistance to antimicrobials is a major public health concern. All antimicrobial drugs can select micro‐organisms that are resistant, whether they are authorised as growth promoters or veterinary medicines or human medicines. For this reason, the Commission is addressing the problem in a comprehensive way.

The Commission has asked the Scientific Steering Committee to examine this question and its relationship with the use of antimicrobials in human and veterinary medicine, animal husbandry and plant protection. If necessary, the Commission shall propose measures in the light of this scientific opinion, which should be available around April next year.

The Commission has also initiated or is involved in a number of other projects to address this important question:

‐ EARSS, The European Antimcrobial Resistance Surveillance System, has started in March 1998. The pilot phase will concentrate on two pathogens, streptococcus pneumoniae and staphylococcus aureus ;

‐ a Fair project on epidemiological surveillance of antimocribial resistance in bacteria of animal origin started in September 1998;

‐ Enter‐net, a surveillance network, which covers human salmonellosis and E. COLI 0157, is including antibiotic resistance in salmonella isolates;

‐ in September 1998, the Commission supported the Community conference on the microbial threat in Copenhagen, which resulted in recommendations for future initiatives;

‐ also in September 1998, the Commission started an inventory on nosocomial infections;

‐ in agreement with the feed additive industry, a two‐year surveillance programme started in spring 1998 to study the resistance in enterococci to antibiotics authorised as additives in six Member States;

‐ a Community financed research project has started this year involving four Member States aiming to study the diversity of enterococci, especially dynamics and occurrence of strains resistant to antimicrobials in the food chain.

The Commission, in cooperation with the Community reference laboratory for zoonoses, is currently preparing the fourth report on trends and sources of zoonotic agents covering the results from 1997. The report will include information from all 15 Member States and contain data on different salmonella phagetypes from several Member States. The Commission is working with the Community reference laboratory and respective national laboratories to further improve and deepen the quality of information on zoonoses. The Commission has also started a project concerning a scientific evaluation of the arrangements for dealing with zoonoses in the Member States. Antibiotic use and resistance will be included.

Moreover, the topic of antimicrobial resistance is being considered as a priority within the Community network for the epidemiological surveillance and control of communicable diseases, set up by the joint decision of the European Parliament and the Council (2119/98/EC).

The Commission must admit that the implementation of the requirements relating to the monitoring and control of certain serotypes of salmonella in poultry breeding flocks laid down in the zoonoses directive is not satisfactory and that the zoonoses reporting system can be considerably improved. The Commission is at present examining how this can best be achieved. However, in view of the complicated nature of the questions involved, the Commission believes that additional time is needed to complete the work before it can make proposals for major legislative changes. The Commission will therefore present shortly a proposal in order to grant an additional time period for the Commission to complete its work. This will allow it to carefully consider all aspects that need to be dealt with in order to ensure optimal consumer protection. The specific problem with multidrug resistant bacteria will certainly be addressed in the context of the revision.

Question No 75 by Ulla Sandbæk (H−0944/98)

Subject: The disabled and public transport

What will the Commission do to ensure that disabled people are given the opportunity to use public transport, including buses, and what will the Commission do to ensure that production of public transport, including buses, is discontinued until such time as a directive is in place to ensure that such transport is accessible to everyone?

Does the Commission not agree that failure to ensure that disabled people can use public transport is contrary to the letter and underlying principles of standard UN rules on equal opportunities for the disabled?

Answer

The Commission can confirm for the honourable Member that a proposal for a European Parliament and Council Directive on buses and coaches, which was passed on to Parliament on 17 October 1997, takes disabled people very much into consideration, including those in wheelchairs.

The dual objective of this proposal is, on one hand, to harmonise the technical regulations that are in force in the Member States, which often differ greatly, and on the other hand, to promote the development of Community social and transport policies.

In particular, the technical annexes I‐B, III and VII to the proposal specify lowered flooring, retractable steps and aids for entering and leaving in order to improve accessibility for this category of users.

This proposal, which is still at first reading in the European Parliament, was the subject of a long investigation aimed at determining the correct balance between the industrial and economic interests of companies and the concerns of the Community"s social policy.

Since this directive has not been published, the national regulations that already exist in the Member States still apply. In any case, it is out of the question to discontinue the production of these public transport vehicles.

Moreover, the Commission is well aware of the rules laid down by the United Nations, and those relating to equal opportunities for the disabled, notably rule No 5 on accessibility, which states that countries must implement action programmes to make the physical environment more accessible. The Commission takes this rule into consideration when drawing up proposals for directives on the accessibility of means of transport.

Question No 76 by Per Gahrton (H−0946/98)

Subject: Antibiotics in animal feed

In the latest issue of LAND (2/10‐98), Commissioner Fischler is reported as having promised that Sweden can maintain its ban on antibiotics in animal feed indefinitely. Will the Commission therefore explain precisely what the Swedish government has been told about how the legal issues are to be resolved so that Sweden can safely maintain its antibiotics ban indefinitely even though the EU is not introducing a similar ban itself? Will it also say whether this is to be regarded as setting a precedent, so that no Member State, new or old, can ever be forced to water down its environmental or health protection rules for the sake of harmonising legislation within the EU?

Answer

The Commission has never assured Sweden that it could maintain the ban on antibiotics in animal feed indefinitely. Such a promise would be incompatible with the accession treaty, which expressly stipulates that Sweden"s special regulations expire on 31 December 1998. To be honest, modifying the accession treaty does not seem to be a realistic alternative.

It is true that Sweden has asked for an extended ban at Community level on antibiotics added to animal feed, but it only presented scientific evidence of this on 2 February 1998. Moreover, that is why the Commission will not be able to make a decision on all the requests for bans before the end of the year. In such a short time, the relevant scientific committees will only be able to take a position on some of the issues in question. Nevertheless, in a few cases where the scientific committee"s opinions are available and where it is considered that these antibiotics must be reserved for medicine, the Commission intends to propose a ban very shortly.

Question No 77 by Heidi Hautala (H−0960/98)

Subject: Research into risks associated with antibiotics

According to the Swedish press, antibiotics are being used to combat plant diseases in a number of EU countries. Livestock farmers in Denmark are undertaking to limit the use of antibiotics as feed additives to promote growth, as resistance to antibiotics has been shown to have caused a death. Microbicidal substances used in household cleansing products may also be transferred from genetically modified plants to human beings.

Has the Commission taken any action to stop the use of antibiotics as growth promoters in animal feedingstuffs? Is the Commission aware of the findings published in Sweden, and will it take action with regard to the use of antibiotics to prevent plant diseases? Will the Commission investigate in full the purposes for which antibiotics are used, the risks associated with them and the measures which should be taken to combat the hazards?

Answer

With regard to the use of antibiotics for plant protection purposes, the Commission noted registrations of products containing kasugamycin (registered in ES, EL, NL), streptomycin (registered in BE, NL, EL, A) and of oxytetracyclin (registered in EL).

They were subjected in the Member States to scientific risk assessments before their uses were authorized, which included estimation of the risks to applicators and to consumers of treated agricultural products.

Notwithstanding these assessments at Member State level, the Commission has given follow‐up, within the framework of the Standing Committee on Plant Health, to questions recently raised by Sweden, in order to assess in more detail the conditions for use and the quantities used.

Moreover, these substances will be evaluated at Community level under Directive 91/414/EEC in the framework of the review programme for existing active substances.

The Commission considers that the problem of the development of anti‐microbial resistance in microorganisms is a major, complex problem of international dimensions. A number of converging reports have been published by the scientific community and by international and national organisations coming to this conclusion. This is the reason why the Commission has asked the Scientific Steering Committee to examine this question of antimicrobial resistance and its relationship with the use of anti‐microbials in human and veterinary medicine, animal husbandry and plant protection.

In the meantime, the Commission will propose in the next weeks the prohibition of four antibiotics used in feedingstuffs in order to preserve their use, or the use of molecules of the same family of antibiotics, to human medicine.

Question No 78 by José Valverde López (H−0947/98/rev. 1)

Subject: Rules for EU administrative procedure

The Union Treaty contains the essential framework of a legal regime for the administration of the Union, describing its institutions and bodies and setting out their respective powers.

The administrative acts of the EC, which arise from its administrative powers, must logically be governed by procedural rules.

The public tends to perceive the EC administration as lacking in transparency and as having excessive powers of discretion, with a proliferation of procedures, requirements and deadlines. In the face of this administrative complexity, which impedes public awareness and leads to inefficiencies, can the Commission provide information on its plans for drawing up a set of rules for the Union's administrative procedure?

Answer

This question involves two separate issues: on one hand, the organisation of the legislative procedures at Union level, and on the other hand, the procedures for the internal running of the institutions. The current Commission has launched a series of initiatives aimed at simplification and greater transparency in these two areas. It has also taken the lead in simplifying interinstitutional procedures, in close cooperation with Parliament and the Council.

The Union"s legislative procedures were not only exhaustively discussed during the negotiations that led to the drawing up of the Treaty of Amsterdam, but the Commission went further and launched ambitious plans aimed at a thorough reform of the way in which the main policies are managed: Agenda 2000, the reform of the CAP and the Structural Funds, and simplification initiatives, which also include the so‐called ‘comitology" issues.

From the point of view of internal management, the Commission has a certain number of tools available that are also to be reviewed in the context of ‘the Commission of tomorrow" action. The Commission"s internal regulations, as well as their conditions of application and the procedure manual, are the basic elements of this.

Question No 79 by Laura González Álvarez (H−0948/98)

Subject: Resumption of military manoeuvres on the El Teleno shooting range (León‐Spain)

Following the fires which broke out in September 1998 as a result of military manoeuvres on the El Teleno (León) shooting range and which proceeded to destroy 5000 hectares of pine forest, such manoeuvres are due to be resumed even though the issue has not yet been resolved nor responsibility apportioned.

Does the Commission not think that the resumption of military manoeuvres before the full extent of the devastation has been brought to light and in the knowledge that the disaster occurred as a result of firing exercises constitutes an attack on the integrity of the people of Luyego and a serious threat to the forestal areas which have already been so badly damaged by fire?

Answer

A significant proportion of the forest fires in Europe are due to negligence where the particular care that is necessary during high‐risk periods for forest fires is not always taken into consideration.

The behaviour of public authorities in this area, and particularly military manoeuvres, certainly do not come within the Commission"s powers. However, the Commission tries, in the context of forest protection plans presented by a Member State as Community action to prevent forest fires, to combat essentially the causes of forest fires and to also reduce the risks resulting from activities relating to law and order.

Question No 80 by Anne McIntosh (H−0955/98)

Subject: Common Fisheries Policy enforcement

What future enforcement measures does the Commission envisage implementing in relation to the Common Fisheries Policy?

Answer

In 1997, inter alia as a result of discussions held with the various Member States, the Commission decided that a new impetus needed to be given to the fisheries control system, since the existing system had proved to have major shortcomings.

In order to make the control system more effective, a global approach was required. A decision was therefore taken to open a general debate on the issues at stake. The Commission submitted to the Council and the European Parliament a communication on fisheries monitoring under the CFP(8) . Parliament adopted a resolution on that communication at its part‐session in September 1998 (Provan report – A4‐0277/98).

In response, the Commission submitted the following documents:

1. a proposal for the amendment of the ‘control' regulation(9) , on which Parliament gave its opinion at its first October part‐session (Teverson report – A4‐0331/98);

2. an action plan to improve the implementation of the common fisheries policy(10) .

The Commission invites the honourable Member to refer to these two documents, which outline the overall approach proposed and show how the various provisions fit into a global strategy.

Question No 81 by Inger Schörling (H−0959/98)

Subject: The pesticide Roundup

Roundup, the active ingredient of which is glyphosate, is one of the world's biggest selling pesticides. Research shows that glyphosate has mutagenic effects and that it decomposes very slowly in the environment. Despite these facts, in applying for Roundup to be authorised as a pesticide, its manufacturer stated that it did not have mutagenic effects and that it decomposed relatively quickly in the environment. Recent measurements taken in waterways in southern Sweden have produced readings of 1.0 microgramme of glyphosate per litre of water, which is ten times the quantity of pesticide residues allowed under EU water directives.

Has the Commission taken heed of these facts? If not, does it intend to? What does it intend to do to overcome this problem if the research shows that the problem exists?

Answer

Council Directive 91/414/EEC provides the legal framework to investigate the safety of new and existing pesticides. This is being done with the utmost scientific scrutiny and according to Uniform Principles. As an existing substance, Glyphosate is currently under evaluation by Germany, the designated Rapporteur Member State. On receipt, by the Commission, of the evaluation it will be peer reviewed by Member State experts and a follow up examination by the Scientific Committee for Plants is also provided for.

Notwithstanding the Community‐wide review of the active substance, national authorisations for sales products are granted only, if under the specific conditions of use in the respective Member State no risk to the applicator, consumer or the environment is to be expected.

This means that the placing on the market and use of products containing Glyphosate will be authorised in Member States only if it is demonstrated that under local conditions its decomposition in the environment is sufficiently fast as to exclude any unacceptable accumulation.

With respect to the honourable Member's concern towards a potential mutagenicity of Glyphosate the Commission would like to indicate that – without prejudice to the final conclusion of the ongoing review – the substance has not been classified as mutagenic or genotoxic in the Community.

Question No 82 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−1021/98)

Subject: Severe risks to consumers' and farmers' health and to the environment from extensive and uncontrolled use of pesticides

The World Health Organization attributes 5000 deaths per year to the use of pesticides, while recent studies have once again revealed the severe risks to the health of consumers and farmers themselves and to the environment from the extensive use of pesticides and combinations of such products. Many of these substances are in fact prohibited but a ban in one country does not automatically mean a ban on the export and use of the product in another. The USA, for example, exports over 64 000 tonnes of prohibited pesticides to Third World countries, which then supply the American and European markets with their products.

What measures will the Commission take to protect consumers' and farmers' health and the environment, within the EU and internationally, so that they do not remain at the mercy of the big chemical industries, which continue to export products banned in one country to others?

Answer

The Commission recognises that, although indispensable in modern agriculture, if used improperly, pesticides may present risks for human health and the environment. Therefore the Community has developed an extensive legislation aiming to control and reduce such risks, mainly in the framework of Directive 91/414/EEC for the placing of plant protection products on the market. The main objectives of this directive are to (a) ensure a high level of protection of human health, for the consumer and for the producers of agricultural commodities, (b) ensure a high level of protection of the environment and resources and (c) ensure free circulation of plant protection products and agricultural produce in the Community.

The directive provides for a positive list of accepted active substances that are considered as safe for human and animal health and the environment after a thorough evaluation. A major programme for review of all plant protection products has been started, involving industries, Member States and the Commission. One of the results of the programme will be the elimination of all such products that do not satisfy the high safety requirements of the directive. However, the authorisation of individual products remains within the responsibility of Member States (subsidiarity) and this constitutes a second check of the safety of a plant protection product under the specific conditions of use in that Member State.

As far as the import and export of dangerous pesticides is concerned, the Community plays a leading role in the international arena and on 9 September last, signed the Prior Informed Consent (PIC) Convention on improved trade in hazardous chemicals and pesticides. This scheme prohibits exportation of certain listed chemicals and pesticides without a written consent from the authorities of the importing country. This scheme initially covers 22 pesticides and extends the already strict mandatory controls in place in the Community under Council Regulation 2455/92 (concerning the export and import of dangerous chemicals).

Question No 83 by Charlotte Cederschiöld (H−0961/98)

Subject: Disciplinary measures for leak of information concerning Commission recruitment competition

It has emerged that an official within the Commission handed out copies of the Commission's recruitment test for 1997 in advance. Does the Commission consider that a two‐year freeze on promotion is a reasonable disciplinary measure or does the Commission stand by Commissioner Liikanen's comment in Parliament on 6 October that we cannot have officials who break the rules even at the point of recruitment?

Answer

The Commission would like to inform the honourable Member that, following the conclusion of the disciplinary proceedings, the appointing authority decided to punish the official concerned by dismissing him.

Question No 84 by Nuala Ahern (H−0963/98)

Subject: Radioactive pollution linked to Dounreay and Sellafield nuclear plants, as documented in a major study by the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programm (AMAP)

A major study drawn up by the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme (AMAP) – which is based in Norway – and presented to the Arctic Council Conference meeting in Iqaluit, Canada, last month alleges that serious pollution of food, plants and animals have affected the Arctic circumpolar area. The eight‐nation Arctic Council is concerned about the potential health and environmental risks posed by radioactive pollution from nuclear reprocessing at the Sellafield and Dounreay nuclear plants, especially by the measured levels of the reprocessing radioactive waste, technetium−99. What action is the Commission taking to tackle this significant environmental problem?

Question No 85 by Alex Smith (H−0975/98)

Subject: Radioactive pollution

A report by Rob Edwards in the ‘Scotland on Sunday' newspaper of 27 September 1998 reveals serious concerns, expressed at the Circumpola Conference of the eight‐nation Arctic Council held in Iqaluit in northern Canada last month, that radioactive pollution, including technetium−99 contamination, has been detected in Arctic plants and animals. The 859‐page Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme report presented to the Inuit Conference blames some of the radioactive pollution on discharges from nuclear reprocessing plants at Dounreay in Scotland and Sellafield in England. Will the Commission investigate the allegations raised at the Circumpola Conference as a matter of urgency?

Joint answer

It is well known that radioactive contamination in Arctic waters extending both eastwards and westwards from the northern Norwegian coast is attributable in part to discharges from Sellafield. However, the concentrations measured correspond to levels of public exposure far below those which might indicate any significant risk to health. The data in the report of the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme confirms this to be the case.

The spread of contamination from Sellafield reflects the long‐range dispersion path of discharges round the Scottish coast. The initial detection of caesium−137 in Arctic waters followed the peak in Sellafield discharges in the mid‐seventies, since when such discharges have been reduced by about a factor of 100. While Dounreay discharges must follow the same long‐range dispersion path, the quantities discharged from that site are not comparable with those from Sellafield and any contribution by Dounreay to contamination of Arctic waters remains theoretical.

The major increase in recent years to technetium−99 in Sellafield discharges has given rise to only a small fraction of the radiation dose limit being received by the most exposed members of the local population. The corresponding exposure of Arctic populations following dispersion and major dilution of the technetium−99 will clearly be substantially smaller than that received locally. Nevertheless, steps are being taken by the United Kingdom authorities to reduce the Sellafield discharge limit for this nuclide in application of the principle that all exposure should be as low as reasonably achievable.

Question No 86 by Niels Sindal (H−0965/98)

Subject: Attacks on long‐distance lorry drivers

I have heard from several Danish hauliers and drivers of an increasing number of attacks on long‐distance drivers who have been held up while carrying out their work, savagely set upon and robbed of their lorries.

Reports from German, French and Italian main roads and motorways, in particular, confirm these claims.

Is the Commission aware of these circumstances and, if so, what initiatives has it taken to resolve these problems?

If the Commission is not aware of these circumstances, will it help to bring the matter up at the next Council meeting with a view to clarifying the extent of the problem?

Answer

The Commission has no precise information on the facts referred to by the honourable Member.

It seems, however, that such attacks on long‐distance lorry drivers are committed by local criminals. It is up to the Member States to ensure public order and security through their law enforcement forces on their territory and to take the appropriate preventive and investigative measures.

Question No 87 by David Martin (H−0966/98)

Subject: The Directive on Parental Leave and Leave for Family Reasons

Can the Commission say whether all Member States required to do so (by June 1998) had reported on the implementation of the Directive on Parental Leave and Leave for the Family and when will the Commission be publishing its own report on the implementation by Member States? Given the diversity of provision that exists in this area does the Commission have plans for further measures?

Answer

Directive 96/34/EC on parental leave came into force on 3 June this year. Italy has not informed the Commission of any national measures implementing this directive. Portugal has sent its existing legislation, but needs further legislation to complete its national implementation. Luxembourg has sent the Commission draft legislation, due to come into force in 1999, implementing the parental leave directive. Infringement proceedings have been launched against these Member States.

Ireland and Austria have informed the Commission that they intend to take advantage of the possibility granted by the directive of delaying implementation of the directive, by 6 months in Ireland and one year in Austria.

The remaining Member States have sent the Commission their national implementing measures.

The Commission will be studying the national implementation of the Parental Leave Directive. The directive does not formally require the Commission to publish a report on its implementation, but in the light of its examination of the national measures it will consider whether such a report should be drafted. The directive sets out minimum requirements. The Member States have taken advantage of the flexibility offered by the directive, and national implementation varies fairly widely. It is too early to say whether any further measures are necessary.

Question No 88 by Francisco Sanz Fernández (H−0969/98)

Subject: Interdepartmental group – Plan of Action against Racism

On page 8 of issue 2 of ‘FORUM' (July 1998), a magazine published by Directorate‐General V/2 (Information and Publications/Informatrix Centre), it says that the Commission will establish an interdepartmental group, independent from the Commission, to implement the Plan of Action against Racism.

Has such a group been established? Who is it composed of? What were the selection criteria?

If the group has not been created yet, when will it be?

Answer

The cited text of the magazine ‘Forum' is: 'An interservice group will be established within the Commission to push this process forward' .

This interservice group has now been created and is composed of representatives of the interested services of the Commission. The aims of this group are:

‐ mainstreaming a specific anti‐racism perspective into all relevant Community policies;

‐ ensuring the effective implementation of the mainstreaming of an anti‐racism perspective;

‐ making use of the experiences gained in mainstreaming a gender perspective into Community policies.

Question No 89 by Edgar Schiedermeier (H−0970/98)

Subject: Payment of annuities and pensions in Greece to Greek nationals living in another EU Member State

Why must annuities and pensions in Greece always be transferred to accounts at domestic banks, all those Greek recipients of annuities and pensions who are resident in another EU Member State thus incurring considerable expense in having the money transferred to it? What action does the Commission intend to take against this practice?

Answer

The honourable Member raises a question concerning the way Greek pensions are paid to persons residing in other Member States.

Article 10 of Regulation (EEC) No 1408/71(11) provides that pensions shall not be subject to any reduction by reason of the fact that the recipient resides in the territory of another Member State other than that in which the institution responsible for payment is situated.

Article 53 of the implementing Regulation 574/7l1 in conjunction with Annex 6 of this Regulation states that Greece pays pensions directly to the entitled persons residing in another Member State.

The question implies that Greece is not respecting this method of payment. However, the question does not contain enough information to enable the Commission to assess whether or not Community law has been respected.

The Commission would invite the honourable Member to submit more details so that it may examine them in the light of Community law.

Question No 90 by Caroline Jackson (H−0972/98)

Subject: Implementation of the milk super levy in Italy

What action has the Commission taken to ensure that individual Italian producers who became liable for the super levy in 1996/97 were in fact made to pay? What has happened since the Commission's written reply of 17 February 1998(12) in which the initiation of infringement proceedings against Italy was mentioned and has any individual Italian milk producer, in the Commission's view, yet paid any money under the super levy?

Answer

In accordance with Article 2 of Regulation No 3950/92, Italian legislation on milk quotas obliges the purchaser to deduct an advance on the levy payable in cases where the quantities delivered by the producer exceed the reference quantity available to that producer. This deduction is made in respect of all deliveries which exceed the individual reference quantity. Since under‐utilisation by other producers is not taken into account at this stage, the advances deducted by purchasers can exceed the levy which is finally found to be payable. The Italian authorities judged this to be the case at the end of 1996 and authorised a partial reimbursement. The balance of the advances paid in respect of the two periods concerned – namely, ITL 433 billion (ECU 216 million) – is still being withheld. Infringement proceedings for failure to comply with Community legislation were initiated against Italy on 12 January 1998, on the grounds that, inter alia, the purchasers failed to pay to the relevant authorities the levy payable for the periods 1995‐1996 and 1996‐1997. On 4 May 1998, the Commission delivered a reasoned opinion to Italy, pursuant to Article 169 of the EC Treaty.

The Italian authorities considered it necessary, before such payment was made, to carry out a thorough check on the level of the individual reference quantity for each producer and that of overall production for the years concerned. Although the results of these checks are, for the moment, still provisional, the Italian authorities believe that they will be able to close the books for the periods concerned in the near future, on the basis of the final results.

Question No 91 by Simon Murphy (H−0979/98)

Subject: Socrates

Is the Commission aware that the reciprocity rule enshrined in the new Socrates programme will lead to sharp reductions in the number of EU students studying in British Universities?

Answer

The Commission proposals on the second phase of the Socrates programme, which is to start in early 2000, does not explicitly mention the reciprocity rule cited by the honourable Member, who is probably referring instead to the decision covering the current Socrates programme, which does refer to ‘balanced participation' between various Member States and disciplines (Annex on implementation of the Erasmus programmes, Action 2, point 2, second subparagraph). This provision was already in force in the two earlier stages of the Erasmus programme and was carried over to the current phase and included in the new proposals currently before the Council and the European Parliament.

The Commission is anxious to ensure that cooperation arrangements are established between all the Member States and to encourage in particular close cooperation with those Member States with less widely‐spoken languages and higher education systems which are less well‐known. Universities and students of course have their own preferences and tend mainly to be drawn towards certain Member States, particularly those with the most widely‐spoken languages. However, thanks to the implementation of the above provision, it has been possible to achieve a highly satisfactory degree of cooperation in terms of student mobility between the Member States participating in the Erasmus programme. For example, although in the initial phase of the Erasmus programme in 1997 student mobility was mainly confined to France, Germany and the United Kingdom, it has now spread to all the Member States involved. Although the principle of reciprocity forms the basis for balanced cooperation, the Commission has always interpreted it in a very broad fashion by inviting the universities involved in the cooperation arrangements to state on what terms and up to what point this principle can be implemented. To this end, the Commission has made a questionnaire available to all universities on its Europa server (see annex).

Question No 92 by John Cushnahan (H−0981/98)

Subject: Competition

In view of the consistent similarity in the prices offered by Irish meat factories to Irish farmers, will the Commission investigate the widely‐held suspicion that the factories are operating as a cartel?
