The Commission has to date not received any complaints from interested farmers or otherwise become aware of the alleged price collusion amongst Irish meat processors.

The Commission will, in conjunction with the Irish Competition Authority, make appropriate inquiries into the matter raised by the honourable Member, which, however, appears to have been the subject of recent initiatives on the part of the Irish Government.

Question No 93 by Arthur Newens (H−0982/98)

Subject: Western Sahara

Would the Commission make a statement on its policy towards the referendum being organised in the Western Sahara and the possibility of sending observers and the provision of subsequent aid?

Answer

The Commission is closely monitoring implementation of the United Nations plan for the settlement of the conflict in the Western Sahara and at the same time providing support. In addition to the substantial humanitarian aid which it has provided to Western Saharan refugees, it is willing to consider all requests for funding in accordance with its own exclusive powers or in close coordination with the Member States under the second pillar of the TEU.

According to the information in the Commission's possession, it is rather premature at this stage to consider whether to send electoral observers or contribute financially towards the repatriation or reintegration of refugees, since extremely slow progress is being made with the drawing up an electoral register. The question of whether to send international observers should be considered at the appropriate time within the framework of the action taken by the United Nations.

Question No 94 by Yiannis Roubatis (H−0984/98)

Subject: Commission's approach to funding for Turkey

The Commission is performing legal contortions – which will have unpredictable consequences and undermine the credibility of the Commission and the Union in general – in drafting a regulation to grant ECU 135 million to Turkey, using Article 130w as the legal basis, which bears no relation whatsoever to Turkey's situation.

Why is the Commission acting in breach of the terms and conditions for strengthening the Union's relations with Turkey laid down by the Council on 6 March 1995, which are contained in the Union's declaration on Turkey of 15 July 1996, the common position of the Association Council of 29 August 1997 and the decisions of the Luxembourg Presidency?

Why is the Commission performing legal contortions and misinterpreting its brief from the Cardiff European Council in order to present funding for Turkey as a ‘technical matter', when it knows that it is a profoundly political act?

How is it possible to accept Turkey as a country eligible for accession and, at the same time, for expediency's sake, to describe Turkey as ‘a developing country'?

Answer

On 4 March 1998 the Commission presented to the Council a communication to prepare Turkey for accession entitled the 'European Strategy for Turkey: the Commission's initial operational proposals' .

The Cardiff European Council on 15 and 16 June 1998 welcomed the communication as a platform for developing relations between the Community and Turkey on a sound and evolutionary basis. It noted that the strategy required financial support and invited the Commission to make the necessary proposals.

To respond to the request made by the Cardiff European Council, the Commission adopted on 21 October two proposals for Regulations:

‐ a Regulation on measures to intensify the EC‐Turkey customs union which would provide Turkey with a total of ECU 15 million during a three‐year period (1999‐2001);

‐ a Regulation on measures to promote economic and social development in Turkey which would provide Turkey with a total of ECU 135 million during a three‐year period (1999‐2001).

Given the stark contrasts characterising Turkey, on the one hand pressing ahead with approximation of its legislation to the Community acquis, but on the other displaying severe regional economic disparities, the Commission had to use two different legal bases.

Question No 95 by Gérard Caudron (H−1020/98)

Subject: Trade relations with Turkey

The Levi Strauss group's decision to transfer the activities of three of its European plants to Turkey, which is known to practise social dumping, calls into question the trade agreements concluded with that country.

In December 1997 Parliament gave its opinion on the Customs Union agreement between the EU and Turkey, which provides for a procedure under which the Commission may take urgent action in the event of anti‐competitive behaviour.

Pursuant to that agreement, how does the Commission intend to ensure that the undertakings entered into in connection with the EC‐Turkey Customs Union are honoured?

Answer

The relocation of industrial activities from the Community to third countries is a consequence of economic growth and competition on a global level. In recent years, many companies, including those in the textile and clothing sectors, have therefore developed strategies of internationalising their production. In this sense, the decision by Levi Strauss to relocate its activity to Turkey continues with this tendency that companies have of seeking the most competitive production conditions possible.

From a social point of view, according to the information that the Commission has, the Levi Strauss group has entered into consultations with workers" representatives, both at national and Community level, with a view to seeking alternative solutions to the closures, or at least alleviating the social consequences of the closures.

With regard to the transfer to Turkey of part of Levi Strauss" activities, the Commission has no grounds to believe that this decision is contrary to the competition rules laid down in the customs union between the EC and Turkey.

Although Turkey still has certain obligations to fulfil with regard to the customs union, notably in the field of competition, the Commission believes that up until now, this union has been functioning in a generally satisfactory manner. This is the opinion that is found, in particular, in the reports on the development of relations between the Community and Turkey since the entry into force of the customs union, which the Commission presents to Parliament and the Council each year.

Question No 96 by Karin Riis‐Jørgensen (H−0988/98)

Subject: Harmonisation and mutual recognition of standards

What steps has the Commission really taken to ensure that new national requirements and standards do not prevent the application of EU standards and rules? Is it reasonable that Member States and regions constantly plead special circumstances in the form of essential situations, and thereby obtain exemptions from the EU standards/rules in force?

How will the Commission ensure that in the future goods can be exchanged without duplicate controls and in keeping with the internal market?

Is it necessary for all working papers, standards proposals and answers at hearings to be available in three languages and for all countries and interests to agree before a standard is put to the vote in the Member States, since this procedure results in one country being able to impede the process indefinitely with constant reservations and objections?

Answer

1. The adoption of common standards and rules at Community level has precisely the aim of preventing, within a true internal market where the free movement of goods is guaranteed, new national rules and standards that differ from the common system from being adopted in the same fields.

1.1. The adoption of a European standard obliges the national standardisation bodies, even those who voted against it, to transpose it at national level and to withdraw any national standards that are contrary to it. Nevertheless, a ‘national exemption" can be requested for certain aspects of the standard if there is already different national legislation. Such cases are limited.

1.2. The adoption of a regulatory harmonisation measure prevents Member States from maintaining national measures that are contrary to it in the sphere covered by the Community measure. Only an exemption under Article 100(a)(4) of the EC Treaty can be exceptionally granted under very strict conditions (only two exemptions have so far been accepted).

2.
2.2. In fields that have not been harmonised at Community level, the Commission monitors both before and after the emergence of new obstacles to the changes that result, notably, from the non‐respect of the Court"s case‐law prohibiting double checks.

2.1.1. The preventive monitoring is carried out under the framework of the Parliament and Council Directive 98/34/EC consolidating the notification procedure in Directive 83/189/EEC in the field of technical standards and regulations. This directive obliges all Member States to inform the Commission and the other Member States of any technical rule or national standard that it plans to draw up so that the texts that are finally adopted guarantee the smooth running of the internal market. In monitoring the national regulations, the Commission systematically requires that mutual recognition clauses be included, and this was validated by the Court"s ruling of 22 October 1998 (case C−184/96).

2.1.2. The Commission also ensures that there is rigorous a posteriori monitoring of existing national regulations with regard to the free movement of goods (Articles 30 onwards of the EC Treaty), notably through infringement proceedings that can be brought before the Court of Justice. In this respect, the European Parliament and Council Decision 3052/95/EC of 13 December 1995 established a mutual information procedure for national measures that do not conform with the principle of the free movement of goods within the Community.

2.2. In the field harmonised, respect for Community rules actually enables products to benefit from free movement within the Community, without monitoring being repeated. For this purpose, EC labelling provides a useful indication of whether the rules in question are being respected.

3. European standards are drawn up and adopted by European standardisation bodies, which are independent bodies with their own internal rules. The public survey and the decision on the national position are taken according to the methods established by each national standardisation body.

The working documents are adopted in the technical committees on the basis of a consensus. The voting rules for these European standardisation bodies do not allow one member to block the process.

Question No 97 by Niall Andrews (H−0990/98)

Subject: Saving the microcredit movement

As the Commission is aware, the recent and severe floods in Bangladesh have threatened the future of the microcredit system in that country with as many as half the borrowers failing to make their weekly repayments due to losses to their livestock, crops and houses. Bank reserves are too small to enable repayments to be frozen and bridging loans are unlikely.

What does the Commission consider can be done to support the Bangladesh microcredit movement which has prompted similar schemes in Latin America, Africa and even Chicago's inner city?

Answer

The Commission has monitored very closely the situation created by the disastrous floods which have affected the country and has already approved a package of 35 MECU in food and emergency aid.

The Commission, through its Delegation in Dhaka, has also made an assessment of the dangers caused by the floods on the ongoing EC‐funded projects.

Most of these projects have a microcredit component and the assessment exercise showed that the revolving loan fund has been particularly affected since group members have not been able to respect the schedule for loan reimbursement and even less to make savings.

Although the Government of Bangladesh is taking measures to ensure fresh funds to relaunch microcredit activities, considering the important needs, the Commission is studying the possibility of increasing up to 20 % of the global commitment of the ongoing projects. Part of these funds will go to refinance the existing businesses concerned by EC projects.

Besides, the Commission is a member of the Local Consultative Group on Microfinance. This group has financed a study entitled: ‘Impact of floods on Microfinance in Bangladesh'. The results of this study are already available and the donors are coordinating their actions in order to provide an appropriate response to this problem.

Question No 98 by Marialiese Flemming (H−0993/98)

Subject: Irradiation of foodstuffs and consumer information

Is the Council aware of the fact that the majority of people living in the European Union are opposed to the irradiation of foodstuffs?

What measures is the Council planning, in addition to existing ones, to provide consumers with unambiguous and comprehensive information on the treatment of foodstuffs and their additives and on the general quality of foodstuffs?

Answer

The Commission would like to remind the honourable Member that its 1988 proposal for a directive harmonising national legislation on the treatment and marketing of foodstuffs treated with ionising radiation was the subject of detailed discussions that reflected consumers" concerns before a common position was approved in 1997 by 14 Member States.

This common position of the Council includes two directives.

It includes a framework directive on the general aspects, including monitoring, and an implementing directive comprising the list of products authorised for treatment with ionising radiation at Community level.

A conciliation procedure is taking place that will be concluded on 27 November. At the first official meeting of the Conciliation Committee, the delegation from the European Parliament stressed the need to adopt these directives.

The provisions on consumer information regarding products treated with ionising radiation can be found in the common position on the framework directive (OJ C 389 of 22 December 1997).

Article 6(1) sets out specific labelling measures informing the consumer of the fact that the foodstuff or its ingredients have been treated with ionising radiation.

Question No 99 by Esko Seppänen (H−0994/98)

Subject: Future of the TACIS programme

In its report on the budget the European Parliament placed some of the appropriations for the TACIS programme in the reserve and demanded, as a condition for the continuation of aid, that Russia keep on course with its reform policy. Does the Commission consider that Russia can continue with a reform policy involving free trade in all goods and the free convertibility of currencies, without serious social consequences? What effects would the ending of the reform policy have on the EU's attitude to Russia's membership of the WTO?

Answer

The Russian Prime Minister has consistently pledged to keep Russia on the track of market reforms, while stressing the objective of the establishment of a social market economy close to the ones existing in Europe. So far, the Community has offered to provide renewed momentum under the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) and to refocus its Tacis programme in support of anti‐crisis priorities. Envisaged domains for new or increased Tacis support range from public finance, debt management, tax collection, banking sector restructuring, Central Bank supervision to more general projects, such as promoting institution‐building and Rule of Law, increasing the investment climate and enterprise restructuring. So, the Commission believes the PCA and Tacis can help. As regards additional financial assistance from the IFIs, this has been subjected to the submission of a comprehensive and credible Russian anti‐crisis programme, elements of which have only been adopted very recently and are being currently studied by the IMF as well as by the Community. In this regard, the Commission draws attention to the fact that it proposes to leave the exchange rate float. It does, on the other hand, suggest to introduce stricter exchange controls regarding export earnings, notably in view of tackling capital flight.

It is correct to state that the Russian Government's challenges are formidable if one considers that it may confront difficult choices such as between either defaulting on its debt or leave its civil servants unpaid.

The Community considers Russia's WTO process to be crucial. It remains a powerful lever to guide Russia towards sustainable trade policy reforms. The Commission reiterated these points at high‐level meetings with its Russian partners in September and October.

Question No 100 by Karl Habsburg‐Lothringen (H−0995/98)

Subject: European Observatory on National Family Policies

On 6 April 1998 the Commission wrote to the Austrian Institute for Family Research mandating it to manage the European Observatory on National Family Policies. Why have six months elapsed between the written confirmation and the forwarding of the contract? Will the Commission pay for work carried out since 6 April?

Question No 101 by Kurt Malangré (H−0996/98)

Subject: European Observatory on National Family Policies

Does the Commission really intend to do away with budget appropriations used hitherto for political measures and projects concerning Member States' family policy? If so, why?

Question No 102 by Bernd Posselt (H−0997/98)

Subject: European Observatory on National Family Policies

What information does the Commission have on the long‐term effects of demographic trends in Europe on its economic growth and prosperity? What contribution do families make to this? Does the Commission regard such issues as important, for example in the light of the future situation on the labour market? If so, why are budget appropriations to research these matters being cut?

Joint answer

Under the 1998 Community budget, measures and projects in respect of demography and family issues and policies in the Member States are funded through heading B3‐4108. Execution of this heading was suspended on 10 June 1998 following a ruling by the Court of Justice in case no C−106/96(13) . Following the review undertaken by the Commission and the Interinstitutional Agreement reached on 17 July 1998, funding from budget line B3‐4108 was unblocked for activities relating to demography, since there is explicit mention of this issue in the EC Treaty (Article 7 of Protocol No 14 on Social Policy) as well as for those activities where promoters could have legitimate expectations of funding before the decision to suspend the budget lines was taken. For that part of the line earmarked for measures and projects in respect of family policies without a demographic perspective, however, funding could not resume since there is no legal basis.

On 6 April 1998, the Austrian Institute for Family Studies (ÖIF) was informed that it had been chosen to coordinate the work of the European Observatory on National Family Policies following an open call for tenders, and that a contract would be prepared to specify the conditions of this provision of services. The procedures relating to the preparation and conclusion of this contract were interrupted because of the suspension of the execution of the relevant budget line. Given that the decision to offer ÖIF a contract was taken before this decision, the Commission decided to conclude the contract with the ÖIF, with effect from the date of its signature, as is foreseen in the case of all contracts for provision of services. The Commission intends to continue funding the activities of the Observatory covered by the Treaty legal basis on demography subject to financial resources.

The overall spending for 1997 and 1998 on this analysis of and research into demography is more than ECU 2 million.

Given that demographic changes have a significant influence on the new profile of the economic landscape, and following the conclusions of the Council of Ministers for the Family (89/C/277/02) of 29 September 1989, the Commission has implemented at Community level an action programme of regular information on demography and on measures concerning the family. This comes under budget line B3‐4108, which in 1998 amounted to a total of ECU 4.5 million.

The Commission believes that, in the long term, demographic development in Europe will have an effect on economic growth and our standard of living.

The same applies for the change in family structure that, added to the new demographic trends, considerably influences the development of the labour market, economic growth and the standard of living in the Community.

Question No 103 by Brian Crowley (H−0999/98)

Subject: The EU and the commercial aspect of sport

Will the Commission indicate what course of action it intends to pursue with regard to its future policy towards the development of sport in the EU, including the commercial aspects of sport, the need to ensure that sporting events are delivered to consumers at a fair price, the question of the dominance of certain media magnates in sport and whether it considers that proposals should be drawn up to limit the often immoral level of transfer fees in football?

Answer

It is not the Commission's job to lay down a model for the development of sport in Europe, since this is primarily the task of the sporting world itself.

However, when called upon to intervene in sports‐related matters, the Commission should naturally attempt to foster the harmonious development of sport in Europe.

It has taken note of the conclusions of the informal Council meeting of sports ministers which identified excessive commercialisation as the main threat to the development of European sport. The Community's competition policy can play an important role in eradicating certain bad practices.

Given that such matters fall with the sphere of consumer protection policy, the Commission will see to it that the ‘Television without frontiers' directive(14) is properly implemented, thus ensuring that major sporting events are available on a free‐to‐air basis, according to the lists adopted by each Member State.

The Commission will also use its powers in the competition sphere wherever necessary in response to the increasingly large‐scale involvement of major media groups in the sports sector.

The Commission's attention will also focus on the rules on the transfer of players laid down by sporting bodies, both in connection with situations covered by the Bosman judgment – in respect of which the Court has established the applicability of Article 48 of the Treaty – and in connection with other situations not covered by that judgment and which may be considered in the light of the competition rules laid down in the Treaty, on condition that the relevant fees are set in an arbitrary manner, i.e. without reference to the cost of training the player concerned. The Commission is actively looking into this matter.

Question No 104 by Concepció Ferrer (H−1000/98)

Subject: Attacks on lorries transporting pig products

Once again there has been an attack on a lorry transporting Spanish products in Brittany. However, on this occasion the lorry was not transporting fruit and vegetables, but processed pig products (17 000 kilos of boned ham), and was attacked by 50 French livestock farmers.

In view of the fact that a number of incidents of this kind have occurred in Brittany, is the Commission aware of these events, which took place on 18 October this year?

Does it intend to take steps to remind France once again about its obligations to ensure compliance with Articles 5 and 7 of the Treaty on European Union?

Answer

The Commission has been informed of numerous violent protests held by pig farmers in Brittany. However, it has not received any complaint or specific information on the events described by the honourable Member. In its ruling of 9 December 1997 in case C−265/95, the Court of Justice set out the obligations of Member States under Articles 5 and 30 of the EC Treaty to put an end to individual acts that threaten the free movement of goods. In the light of this ruling, the Commission will contact the French authorities in order to remind them of these obligations.

In addition, the Commission would like to stress that the European Parliament, on 5 November 1998, demonstrated its political will to eliminate this type of obstacle by approving a proposal for a Council regulation based on Article 235 of the EC Treaty. This proposal provides for a rapid warning system in the case of the threat of obstacles to trade in goods, an obligation for Member States to act rapidly to eliminate the obstacle that is evident in its territory and to inform the Commission of this, as well as intervention from the Commission in the form of an official notification.

Question No 105 by Mark Killilea (H−1006/98)

Subject: Road construction projects

Can the Commissioner state what the main features are of the public planning rules in each of the Member States regarding the road construction projects?

What is the average length of time spent securing planning permission during the preconstruction phase?

Answer

Public planning rules regarding construction of transport infrastructure projects are the responsibility of Member States and vary from one to another. The Commission does not maintain an inventory of the current public procedures for the construction of road projects in each Member State.

However, in the framework of the 1997 High Level Group on Public‐Private Financing, the length and complexity of the planning phase was identified by a number of participants as one of the factors to be taken into account in developing projects as public private partnerships.

Concerning the average length of time spent securing planning permission during the pre‐construction phase, this is directly linked to the characteristics of each individual project. The length of the project, its financing nature (purely public financing or concession), its location (sensitive environmental areas, urban zones..), and political and Community considerations are some of the many elements that can influence the duration of the planning permission. The period is, nevertheless, rarely less than 3 years.

Question No 106 by Per Stenmarck (H−1007/98)

Subject: Safety at sea for passenger vessels

Within a short space of time, two passenger ferries – Estlines' Baltic Kristina and Viking Lines' Gabriella – have been damaged in heavy seas in the Baltic. The Baltic Kristina suffered damage to its bow doors en route from Tallinn to Stockholm. The Gabriella encountered heavy seas in the same area as the Estonia sank four years ago.

The Finnish shipping authority has ordered an inspection of all bow doors on all passenger ferries flying the Finnish flag. Talks are being held about the possibility of introducing wind restrictions for passenger vessels in the Baltic.

In the light of the safety‐enhancing measures introduced in recent years, is the Commission also prepared to examine the possibility of introducing a maximum permissible wind velocity for passenger vessel operation?

Answer

The Commission has examined the possibility of introducing a maximum permissible wind velocity for passenger vessel operation.

Since 1995, the international SOLAS Convention includes in particular two new regulations addressing operational limitations. They require that a list of all limitations on the operation of a passenger ship, including weather and sea state restrictions, whether imposed by the Administration or established during the design or the building stage, shall be compiled before the passenger ship is put into service and kept on board readily available to the master. Further, SOLAS now stipulates the master shall not be constrained from taking any decision, which in his professional judgement is necessary for the safe navigation and operation of his ship, in particular in severe weather and heavy seas.

These SOLAS requirements, applicable to passenger ships engaged on international voyages, have been incorporated into Community law for domestic voyages by Council Directive 98/18/EC on safety rules and standards for passenger ships(15) . Further, with its proposal for a Directive on the conditions for the operation of regular ro‐ro ferry services in the Community(16) , the Commission proposed to enforce the application of these international and European safety measures through a system of mandatory surveys by host States.

Taking into account these safety‐enhancing measures, both existing and proposed, the Commission believes that there is satisfactory safety legislation relating to operational limitations in severe weather and heavy sea conditions. More specific measures are not considered necessary at this stage.

Question No 107 by Jean‐Antoine Giansily (H−1008/98)

Subject: European employment policy

Can the Commission explain what progress has been made in employment policy in the European Union since the Extraordinary European Council meeting on Employment held in Luxembourg on 20 and 21 November 1997, the conclusions of which set out a ‘strategy for national employment policies' and a series of ‘guidelines' which were incorporated in the Commission's 1998 programme, in view of the fact that, following the recent meeting of the Council of Social Affairs Ministers, Mr Junker, the Prime Minister of Luxembourg, paradoxically stated that he had not seen any change in the strategy adopted a year ago, despite claims that the new socialist governments of a number of Member States would take a different approach to European employment policy?

Does the Commission not consider that European citizens are justified in feeling that they have been misled by statements of intent and ostensibly official proposals which have in fact turned out to be mere election propaganda?

Answer

Since the European Council meeting on Employment held in Luxembourg in November 1997, some important and solid steps have been taken.

The Commission sees the fact that Member States are drawing up national employment plans transposing the 1998 guidelines on employment, as well as the presentation of their first implementation reports, submitted in July, as concrete steps in the implementation of the European employment strategy. In a communication adopted in May 1998 and presented to the Cardiff European Council(17) , the Commission presented its first report on implementing the European employment strategy, based on the examination of national plans. The findings from this analysis of the implementation reports are presented in the draft 1998 joint report on employment(18) .

In both cases, a critical analysis highlights indisputable progress, in particular the shift in national policies towards a more preventative approach to unemployment and reinforced incentives for job seekers, and the fact that the operational objectives of the Community are taken into account. This analysis also acknowledges a number of inadequacies or shortcomings, for example in the presentation of concrete measures to respond to the development of entrepreneurial spirit or in including equal opportunities in national political priorities. At this stage, however, an overall evaluation of progress made is not possible without taking into account certain elements which explain the inequality in the progress observed, beginning with the fact that the European employment strategy is a long‐term one.

Therefore, the Commission is aware that 1998 only marks the beginning of a process where real results in terms of a reduction in unemployment, job creation and a reduction in inequality in the job market will only be gradual. On the other hand, the European employment strategy is a far‐reaching one, calling for coordinated and coherent action along four main lines and involving several partners at all levels. Also, there are considerable differences in the respective situations of the Member States.

In accordance with established procedures and in collaboration with the Member States, the Commission intends to make full use of its role as monitor of the commitments made in the national plans and the efforts made to fulfil them. This role is an integral part of the process begun in Luxembourg. The results are presented each year in the joint report on employment and in a proposal for revising the guidelines submitted to the European Council(19) .

Question No 108 by Gerhard Hager (H−1010/98)

Subject: Pre‐accession package – Enlargement eastwards

The conclusion of ‘pre‐accession packages' in the field of asylum, immigration and visa policy and the early adoption of the Schengen standards at the applicant countries' southern and eastern borders are always described as being among the priorities for the preparation of enlargement to include neighbouring countries..

Politicians from the eastern countries (Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic) do not, however, seem to share these views. In Hungary and in the Czech Republic, opposition to an early adoption of EU visa policy is growing. The Polish President cannot imagine imposing strict border checks on the border with Ukraine even after accession. He said he could not reconcile this with his moral principles.

Does the Commission still reckon on the conclusion of such pre‐accession packages, and what is the timescale for doing so?

Answer

On accession, the applicant countries will need to adopt the Union acquis – including, inter alia, in the fields of asylum, immigration and visas.

The individual Accession Partnerships defining the priorities to be observed in adopting the Union acquis have been adopted in March 1998, and then have been transmitted to the candidate countries. Asylum, immigration and visa policy are priorities in the partnerships. Applicants will also need to adopt the acquis resulting from the Treaty of Amsterdam.

In view of the priority given to this in the Accession Partnership, the Commission does not consider the conclusion of additional ‘pre‐accession packages' in this field to be needed.

Question No 109 by Liam Hyland (H−1013/98)

Subject: An ‘environmental audit' for Sellafield including the new MOX plant

Is the Commission aware that the Sellafield Mox plant which has a capacity to produce 120 tonnes a year of MOX fuel, which is a mixture of lethal uranium and plutonium oxides recovered from reprocessing spent nuclear fuel, has just been given the go‐ahead by the British Environmental Agency.

Having regard to the appalling safety record of the overall Sellafield operation, will the Commission carry out an ‘Environmental Audit' and ensure that until such time as its findings are published and examined, all work at the MOX plant will be halted and, furthermore, to give added weight to this argument, does the Commission consider that the terms of Article 78 of the EURATOM Treaty give it the authority to ensure that no techniques which are used for processing irradiated fuels can proceed without the Commission's approval?

Answer

The Commission is specifically empowered under the terms of Article 35 of the Euratom Treaty to verify the operation and efficiency of the facilities Member States are required to provide for environmental radiological monitoring. Such a verification was conducted at Sellafield in 1993 and no significant discrepancies were identified at that time. Meanwhile, operation of the new MOX plant would not in itself suggest a need for additional environmental monitoring facilities.

More generally, it is for the Member States to ensure compliance with the Community Basic Safety Standards for the health protection of the general public and workers against the dangers of ionizing radiation(20) . The Commission may intervene as Guardian of the Treaty only if it has sufficient evidence that a Member State is not in compliance with these standards. There is no such evidence.

The second paragraph of Article 78 of the Euratom Treaty only applies to installations that perform chemical processing of irradiated materials. These conditions are not fulfilled for MOX Fuel Fabrication Plants. Therefore, as far as Article 78 is concerned, a formal approval of the techniques is not required.

Question No 110 by James Fitzsimons (H−1015/98)

Subject: Imports of radioactive mushrooms into EU

Following detection by a European early warning system of imports of mushrooms from Poland, Lithuania, Romania, Belarus and Ukraine which were contaminated by radioactive emissions from Chernobyl, the Commission has called for mushroom import controls to be strengthened and exports from third countries to be certified.

Is the Commission aware of any exports of these radioactively contaminated mushrooms to Ireland and is the Commission now concerned that imports of vegetables and other food products from these countries could still be subject to Chernobyl contamination and, while being very conscious of the importance of exports from these countries, particularly during the prevailing economic difficulties, will the Commission outline how it proposes to deal with this issue?

Answer

Limits on the radioactive contamination of foodstuffs imported into the Community from third countries were first applied in May 1986 immediately after the Chernobyl accident. Such limits remain in force under the terms of Council Regulation 90/737/EEC(21) as amended by Council Regulation 95/686/EC(22) . The types of foodstuffs still concerned are listed in Commission Regulation 727/97/EC(23) , the list includes dairy produce, various types of meat and meat products, berries, herbs, infusions and mushrooms, based on the possible direct or indirect incorporation of radioactive caesium from the soil. Vegetables are no long expected to show any significant incorporation of radioactive caesium from the soil and any surface contamination by soil particles would be removed by normal cleaning prior to consumption.

It is the responsibility of Member States to check imports of such foodstuffs for radioactive contamination and, under the terms of Directive 92/59/EEC on general product safety(24) , to notify the Commission of any consignment breaching the limits. Recently an appreciable number of reports have been received of excessively contaminated mushrooms but no such cases have been reported for Ireland and no other types of foodstuffs have been involved. The Commission has concluded that the extension of the monitoring of imports to each and every consignment of mushrooms already initiated will serve to maintain Community radiation protection standards.

As a result of these repeated cases of non‐compliance with the maximum permitted levels on imports of certain types of mushrooms, the Commission has informed the concerned third countries thereof requesting the concerned countries to put the necessary measures in place in order to guarantee that future exports are not radioactively contaminated at unacceptable levels. The Commission intends furthermore to adopt within short notice detailed and stringent rules for the application of the said Council Regulation (EEC) No 737/90 in order to allow more efficient controls by the competent authorities of the Member States on all the products referred to in Article 4 of that Directive.

Question No 111 by Hugh McMahon (H−1017/98)

Subject: Information Policy and the European Parliament elections in 1999

What resources does the Commission intend to use to publicise next year's European Parliament elections? Does the Commission foresee the provision of extra resources for information policy in the UK, now that it has changed its electoral system and brought it into line with the rest of the EU?

Answer

The Commission intends to include among its existing information measures and instruments a campaign to raise public awareness of the European elections in June 1999. This policy, which was formulated in conjunction with the European Parliament, is already being implemented in the second half of 1998, inter alia as part of the ‘information for European citizens' programme (PRINCE).

Together with the European Parliament and in consultation with the relevant national government departments, the Commission is currently considering the appropriateness and feasibility of further initiatives in the Member States, including the United Kingdom.

Question No 112 by Robin Teverson (H−1018/98)

Subject: Genetically modified organisms

Parliament is currently considering the Commission proposals to amend Directive 90/220/EEC(25) on the deliberate release of genetically modified organisms. The Commission will be aware that a number of Member States have decided to impose their own rules governing the development of genetically modified crops without reference to Union law.

Given increasing public concern, the differing views of Member States, and rapidly changing scientific knowledge in the discipline, when will the Commission bring forward new proposals on the testing and importing of genetically modified crops, proposals which better reflect the concerns of Member States?

Answer

According to the Directive 90/220/EEC on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms, the competent authorities of Member States shall ensure that genetically modified organisms placed on the market as or in products have been granted consent according to the provisions of the Directive. To fulfil this aim, the competent authorities are required to organise inspections and other control measures as appropriate, to ensure compliance with this Directive.

The Commission has established an ad hoc technical Working Group on inspections and control measures in order to ensure a harmonised implementation of these measures in the Member States. The work of the group is continuing to produce technical guidelines to assist the Member States in the development and application of the appropriate control measures.

Accordingly, the Commission is not, at this stage, proposing to develop new proposals under Directive 90/220/EEC on inspection and control measures further to the measures already contained in the Commission proposal amending Directive 90/220/EEC.

Question No 113 by Jan Bertens (H−1025/98)

Subject: Implementation of the budget lines devoted to human rights

The Commission is doing nothing to clarify the situation as regards the implementation of the budget lines devoted to human rights. Why has it not given any insight, as it did in previous years, into expenditure on projects? How does the Commission intend to guarantee the transparency which is customary for the Union?

Why has the Commission not yet signed the contract with the European Human Rights Foundation, the implementing organisation selected as long ago as May 1998? Does the Commission share my view that this contract must be signed at an early date so that the large number of small‐scale projects, which otherwise would not be carried out in 1998, may indeed still be carried out?

Answer

The use of budget lines from Chapter B7‐70, the aim of which is to promote and protect human rights, has met with many obstacles during the 1998 financial year. The main obstacles are:

‐ the consequences of the Court of Justice ruling of 15 May and of the consultation procedure concerning the draft regulations on the legal bases for the human rights lines of Chapter B7‐70, which led to the blocking of all human rights lines until the interconstitutional declaration of 27 July 1998 allowed them to be used on an exceptional basis until December 1998.

‐ the concerns and criticisms expressed by the European Parliament regarding the technical assistance offices (TAO), which led to an increasingly strict interpretation of the Financial Regulation, particularly as regards the use of external staff.

In spite of these obstacles, the Commission has done and will do everything necessary to ensure that appropriations available in Chapter B7‐70 are used as widely as possible, whilst respecting the selection criteria and taking into account geographical priorities and subject priorities. The rate of utilisation for Chapter B7‐70 should reach 80 % towards the end of this month. The procedure followed is the same as in previous years, except for the PHARE‐Democracy and TACIS‐Democracy lines as they are being managed under other human rights lines in the same chapter.

The European Parliament is usually informed by means of ad hoc reports on the different lines and by reports on the different issues.

As regards the situation of the European Human Rights Foundation, it must be specified that the invitation to tender that aims to ensure technical assistance in the field of human rights and democratisation was not finalised. This was due to the fact that, when examined, the terms of the invitation to tender and the procedure adopted were not in accordance with a strict interpretation of the Financial Regulation.

Question No 114 by María Izquierdo Rojo (H−1030/98)

Subject: Lack of safety at school

According to the Commission's information, how many schools in the EU do not have fire escapes? Is the Commission aware of the serious breaches of the regulations governing safety at school? Is an exchange of information and experience among Member States being organised, as provided for in the Council Conclusions(26) ?

Answer

The issue of fire safety in schools falls within the competence of the Member States.

While the fire stairs themselves are construction products and thus must conform with the provisions of the construction products Directive 89/106/EEC(27) , the regulations concerning the use of such stairs remain a national matter.

As for Directive 89/654/EEC(28) concerning minimum health and safety requirements for the workplace, this would only apply to schools as a place of work for certain categories of occupant. It sets out minimum requirements concerning emergency exits. All the Member States have communicated to the Commission the national measures transposing this directive into domestic law. The Commission is currently checking the conformity of these measures with Community law. Nevertheless, it should be pointed out that it is up to the national authorities to check that these measures are properly applied in each Member State. The Commission has no specific information on this issue.

It should also be pointed out that the Council Conclusions to which the honourable Member refers do not directly concern the safety of school buildings but rather the educational aspects involved in promoting ‘safe" education. This is particularly true for preventing and managing violence and incivility, as well as for promoting educational strategies that aim to achieve the best possible personal development and peaceful socialisation amongst pupils.

Question No 115 by Linda McAvan (H−1033/98)

Subject: Steel

How would the Commission address the steel workers in the UK who number more than 1000 and who have recently learned of restructuring or closure programmes that will affect their employment within the next six months, much of it a direct result of the very difficult trading conditions on the world steel market?

Answer

The Commission shares the honourable Member's anxiety as regards new job losses in the European steel industry, particularly in the United Kingdom.

The European steel industry went through a difficult period. In 1993, the sector faced a new crisis for which the main source was certainly the existing overcapacities. Between 1992 and 1996 some 19 million tonnes of capacities have been closed down. Since then, all European steel companies have been able to present a positive balance sheet. However, the restructuring is and will be a continuous process; therefore, the steel industry needs further adjustments of their production facilities.

The recent redundancies programmed in the United Kingdom are not only directly resulting from the difficult trading conditions in the world steel market, as assumed by the honourable Member, but rather the consequences of a private company's decision facing the costs to modify, modernise and maintain its existing facilities.

According to British Steel, one of the largest producers in Europe, some closures are linked to the strength of the pound, on which the Commission has no power to intervene.

However, it is possible that the Asian crisis and the consequent dramatic changes in trade patterns will have accelerated the decisions that European steelmakers are making.

Concerning these changes in trade patterns of steel, I can say that the Commission is monitoring developments closely and would examine any requests for commercial defence measures on their merits.

The honourable Member can be assured that the Commission will continue its efforts in searching for reconversion of the involved regions in the framework of the Community programme RESIDER II.

Question No 116 by Veronica Hardstaff (H−1037/98)

Subject: Ill‐treatment of citizens at passport control

Is the Commission aware that some EU citizens are being treated by some immigration officials with hostility and contempt as regards their right to travel freely within the Union? I refer particularly to the case of a young female British citizen, travelling from Italy to Britain by train via France, who was bullied physically and verbally, prevented from phoning her family or the British Consulate, and had her passport confiscated by French border officials. No doubt the fact that her mother was originally from Ghana, although now a British citizen, was the major factor which prompted the officials concerned to behave as they did.

Would the Commission take steps to ensure that all officials within the EU dealing with passport/immigration controls receive proper training, including racial awareness courses, to ensure that non‐white Community citizens are not subjected to harassment when exercising their legal right to travel freely within the European Union?

Answer

The Commission deplores the incident reported by the honourable MEP.

The European Union is a space of freedom of movement for all EU citizens and harassment of any EU citizens at borders between Member States is incompatible with this principle. Any harassment motivated by racial discrimination is to be strongly condemned.

The Commission is committed to fight against racism and xenophobia and will use the possibilities offered by the new Treaty of Amsterdam once it has entered into force, in particular as regards Article 13 of the new Treaty. An action plan against racism was tabled in March 1998(29) .

It must be stressed, however, that the fight against racism and xenophobia is essentially an area of national competence. The incident that has been reported by the honourable MEP should be pursued at national level.

Question No 117 by Pedro Marset Campos (H−1043/98)

Subject: Peace process in the Middle East

In view of the importance of EU trade in the Middle East, which represents 70 % of Israel's foreign trade, and noting once again the latter country's systematic failure to comply with the Wye Plantation agreements which are intended to ensure continuity in the peace process, does the Commission not think that it is now time to force Mr Netanyahu to abide by the recently‐signed agreements by blocking all the economic and cooperation agreements concluded between the EU and Israel until such time as the Israeli Government demonstrates its firm intention to continue the peace process?

Answer

The Wye agreement has re‐opened the window of opportunity for peace in the Middle East despite the legitimate doubts that arise regarding its implementation in view of the faulty record of implementation of previous agreements.

There are many hurdles ahead, including terrorist violence and the complexity of further negotiations on a number of crucial issues. Speaking about the Palestinian's commitment to fight terrorism PM Netanyahu has said that it is deeds that count, not merely words. This can and should also be said about his own commitment to peace.

The international community should provide all necessary political and economic support to the parties to guarantee the implementation of the agreement. However, support may not be enough.

It is high time to depart from the culture prevailing in the region of not implementing agreements freely entered into. Too much is at stake, including the future of the Euro‐Mediterranean Partnership.

The Commission has tried, and has partially succeeded, to reverse this trend, notably in its bilateral relations with Israel, demanding that the partners fulfil all of their contractual obligations without exception.

Should the parties, yet again, fail to comply with the commitments that they have freely entered into, the European Union should show the resolve to help them to comply.

Question No 118 by Ivar Virgin (H−1044/98)

Subject: Use of tallow products

Commission Decision 97/534/EC(30) concerning specified risk material and prohibiting the use of tallow and products derived therefrom is to enter into force on 1 January 1999. The various EU scientific committees have stated on several occasions, and most recently in September 1998, that products derived from tallow may be considered to pose no risk if produced under certain specified conditions which render the BSE agent harmless. In spite of such scientific assurances, a number of major sectors of industry (producing plastics, dyes and paints, fertilisers, lubricants, detergents, foodstuffs, animal feed, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, tyres, etc) risk being deprived of tallow, a vital raw material, and thus being forced to halt production within two months.

What steps does the Commission intend to take to remedy this problem? Will products derived from tallow be excluded from Decision 97/534/EC?

Answer

Commission Decision 97/534/EC does not prohibit the use of tallow or the use of tallow derivatives. It does, however, prohibit their use when they are produced from or contaminated with specified risk materials. More precisely, the effect of this decision on Community tallow production would be that animal waste used as raw material will not contain tissues which it defines as specified risk materials.

As far as imports from third countries are concerned, the decision only refers to products for food, animal feed, medical, pharmaceutical and cosmetic purposes or starting materials or intermediate products in respect of certification of freedom from specified risk materials.

However, the Commission is aware of the concern in some quarters, referred to by the honourable Member, that the wording of the decision could give rise to different interpretations. Accordingly, the Commission intends, in the course of amending the decision in the light of new scientific advice, to take the opportunity to clarify the text to make it clear that it does not apply to products which carry no health risk.

Question No 119 by Pierre Pradier (H−1046/98)

Subject: Resumption of cooperation with Burundi

Since the EU suspended its cooperation with Burundi a few months after the seizure of power by Major Buyoya, the Burundian authorities have made moves to bring about national reconciliation, as illustrated by the formation of a coalition government and the decision to authorise the reconstitution of the Burundian Parliament and the political parties. They have also closed the refugee camps, allowed more than 60 % of the refugees to return to their home villages, restored and order throughout the country and implemented reforms, for example in the sphere of justice. Moreover, the Burundian Government is at this moment continuing the Arusha negotiations, thereby demonstrating its determination to see peace prevail. Its moderate approach to the developing conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo likewise bears witness to that determination. When can the Burundian people, already hard hit by the regional embargo, expect to see the statements by Commissioner Pinheiro that European funding for Burundi might gradually be resumed translated into action? Why is the Commission not yet prepared to give the green light for the resumption of EU cooperation with Burundi?

Answer

Cooperation with Burundi was suspended for security reasons in July 1996. Nonetheless, humanitarian aid to the population of Burundi was still maintained.

The Commission has followed with great interest developments both in the country itself and in negotiations with other countries. It considers progress in national dialogue and the Arusha negotiations to be very encouraging.

In view of this, the Commission announced the gradual resumption of cooperation with Burundi, following the adoption by the Burundian National Assembly of a political platform and a transitional constitution in June 1998.

In order to add weight to its intentions, the Commission is currently finalising a support programme for the national assembly and is preparing a support programme for a prison system.

Lastly, the Commission has sent a chargé d"affaires to Bujumbura, who has been there since the end of October 1998, and the Burundian authorities have appointed a national authorising officer. The main task of the chargé d"affaires is to examine, in conjunction with the Burundian Government, the possibility of relaunching projects stopped in 1997 and of using the remaining funds from the 7th EDF, particularly for resettling refugees and displaced persons and for rehabilitation.
